entries: This guide in its inception was intended to inspire DMs to try running D&D in an "East-Asian" fantasy setting. I had unknowingly stepped into a controversy I didn't fully understand at the time, and I am very much still learning. Before you get inside the guide, I'd like to mention the topic of Orientalism and the problematic history D&D has had with it.

TSR published {@i Oriental Adventures} for AD&D in 1985. This supplement unfortunately fell foul of all of the tropes of the West-gazing-East. For example, let's take a look at what it says on the back cover:
{@i "The mysterious and exotic Orient, land of spices and warlords, has at last opened her gates to the West."} (Yikes.)

{@i Oriental Adventures} takes Japanese, Chinese, Mongolian, and Korean ideas and uses them to create a land called Kara-Tur, home of a homogenized East-Asian superculture. The supplement leans heavily on stereotypes and presents the people of Kara-Tur as "violent and savage, uncivilized and in need of foreign saviors and as objects of fetishization" (Daniel Kwan). The authors encode this fetishization of the exotic via a seventh core attribute named Comeliness, which affects how your character is interacted with, and has bonuses or penalties depending on your character's race. (This attribute appeared solely in {@i Oriental Adventures} and {@i Unearthed Arcana}.)

It is this othering of East-Asian cultures, and a determination to blur the lines between them, that I'm slowly coming to understand more about. While there has been a great deal of cultural interaction and exchange in East-Asia, that does not give license for an alien observer like myself to pool many of these cultures for inspiration, take my favorite bits, sandpaper out any nuance, and thus miseducate people.
For that reason I chose to narrow my scope to late Sengoku-era Japan and its folklore. My goal was to create a mirror image of Japan where the animism in Shinto was fully grounded in reality.

The way I chose to go about this was to fully acknowledge my status as an alien, writing as Lafcadio: a man who made a long voyage, experienced cultureshock, and brought back what they had learned to educate those in their homeland. I wrote this way as it was my lived experience. I recognize however that this narrative device made my guide yet one more perpetrator of othering.

Lafcadio was named after the Greek-Irish folklorist Lafcadio Hearn, who travelled to Japan and spent much of his life there. His writings personally inspired me; however, he was also partly responsible for propagating some of the most harmful Orientalist tropes. Since the first edition I replaced Lafcadio with Kunio, a native Seigai citizen. Kunio is inspired by one of Hearn's contemporaries, Yanagita Kunio, who wrote an excellent collection of folk tales named {@i The Legends of Tono}. I recommend this one to any GM—there are times where it reads like a collection of useful plot-hooks.

Additionally, I made much more effort to educate myself on Japanese culture, holding ideals of accuracy and respectfulness in my writing and art selection. Kunio makes sure to point out the fantastical elements of Seigai, as well as its flaws. I am sure I haven't done this perfectly, so please do send me a note if you find areas that fall short of those ideals so that I can amend them in a future edition.

If you choose to run games in Seigai and you are not Japanese (which is probably most of you!), please approach the games you run with those same ideals. You don't have to do it perfectly! But please do it humbly, and lean towards nuance, rather than stereotype.

I would like to take one last paragraph to highlight two educational resources. Firstly the {@i {@link Asians Represent|http://oneshotpodcast.com/interview-discussion/asians-represent/}} podcast, whose work has been an incredible help in the creation of this guide. Secondly, for help with playing a character of another ethnicity, check out James Mendez Hodes' excellent article {@i {@link "May I Play A Character From Another Race?"|https://jamesmendezhodes.com/blog/2019/2/14/may-i-play-a-character-from-another-race}}. Please go and support them, and continue to amplify minority voices.
Thanks for reading the above. I hope you enjoy the guide! —Ross ({@link u/Rosstavo|https://reddit.com/user/Rosstavo})

entries.name: Looking for adventures to run in the land of Seigai?
entries: Try {@i {@link Unbreakable Vol. 1|http://unbreakablerpg.com/}}, a collection of original Asian folklore-themed adventures, written by Asian authors, and easily reskinnable for Seigai.

entries.name: One last thing...
entries: Seigai, much like Japan, consists of not one homogenous culture, but a number of different ethnic groups and cultures. South of Japan is the Ryukyu island chain, home of the Ryukyuan people. Meanwhile, the Ainu people have called Hokkaido in Northern Japan their home for hundreds of years.

Both of these groups have their own language, religion, culture, and traditions. However, since the Meiji government in the 19th century, these two people groups have faced systematic erasure and forced assimilation with the stated goal of unification in order to create a "pure" Yamato ethnicity. Ainu and Ryukyuans still face discrimination to this day. Only in 2019 was a section of the Meiji-era policy unwound with the Ainu Promotion Act, where the Ainu were finally recognised as an indigenous and distinct ethnicity. The Ryukyuan people are not recognised as a minority group at all.

This guide occasionally contains depictions of characters with Ainu and Ryukyuan-inspired heritage in order to broaden your imagination and recognize the wonderful diversity of Seigai, and thus, Japan.

data.name: Prologue
entries: It was a September morning in Bōfūshi. The cicadas in the cedar trees sent shrill melancholic calls into the early dawn, and I arose from my bed to walk the boards to the other wing, where I would prepare breakfast for my guest. Xuurth-san had been staying under my roof for many months now, and while I was grateful for the routine, I did wonder when he would finally have all the material he needed to complete his manuscript.

As I passed Xuurth-san's room, I noticed the warm diffuse glow of the lamps inside. Either he had once again fallen asleep at his desk, or he had been up all through the night. I thought about calling on him, however before I could enquire, the screen door slowly slid open.
"It is complete," announced Xuurthsan with a characteristic deadpan expression. He looked even more dishevelled than usual, and I admit I felt embarrassed for him. He paused in the doorway
"Ah! Good. You must be very pleased," I answered.
"Yes—I suppose so." Xuurth-san stared long at the rolls of paper sheets he held. "I do not think it is very good."
"Oh. I'm sure it is just fine."

He met my eyes for the first time. "No, I believe it needs work. Here—look." He nonchalantly dropped the stack and unrolled a scroll. We glanced through the preface together. He was right, of course. If his observations were calligraphy, it was as if he had made all the right strokes, but not necessarily in the right stroke order.

I let out a long sigh. "Dear friend. You have made a fine go at it. I suppose you may benefit from having access to my writings. They are written with no great imagination; just matter-offact reflections I have made and felt worth recording for posterity. Let me show you to my study." I gave him the warmest, most sincere smile I could muster.
He followed me across the walkway to a room at the back. I dragged open the door and beckoned him in.

My study is no great palace. However as Xuurthsan's eyes roamed across the shelves of boundpocket notebooks, I felt a pride grow within me; a feeling of satisfaction at my own discipline. He reached towards the first shelf and gently pulled a book loose, placing it upon my desk, and began thumbing through the pages.

For the next few months we embarked on a great project together, to attempt to describe each others' country of origin to the other, in a meaningful way for cultural study. At the point of completion, we both shared great contentment and felt thoroughly enriched by the exchange of cultures. He returned to his homeland with a copy of this book, {@i Kunio's Guide to Seigai}. He left me with his own work, {@i Limbo for Terrestrials}. (It is a stellar read.)

As I write this, I can once again hear the cicadas from my study, calling me back to that fresh Autumn morning. The entomologist could tell you that as a cicada reaches the end of its larval stage, it emerges from the surface, shedding its husk on a nearby tree, and takes wing. Indeed, I only regret taking so many years to notice their pattern, and follow its example.

data.name: Welcome to Seigai
entries: In the South-East quarter of the Etrican Islands lies the realm of Seigai. The island consists of two landmasses connected by a narrow land-bridge, resembling the gaping maw of the country's famous {@i ō-ryū} dragons. It has always seemed to me a striking silhouette, like some playful flourish by the {@i kami} who built this land in primordial times.

The land that comprises the upper jaw is named Shōjōshima. This land is rich in minerals and dominated by agriculture; however, as the rich farmland is highly prized, this area has seen much conflict, and has only managed to rebuild in the last twenty years.
Towering over Shōjōshima, the great Mount Yamabi dominates the landscape to the East. Once every hundred years, Mount Yamabi unleashes a terrible eruption that covers the nation in ash.

The remaining portion of Seigai is known as Shōdanshima. This land is less populated than Shōjōshima as the challenging terrain limits travel to the main road, which leads travelers from the capital of Kōtoshi at the neck down to the most remote city of Enfūshi at the chin.

The mountain range known as Seigai's Teeth (Seigai-no-Hanarabi) runs parallel to this main road, with two traversable passages to the city of Akugaku to the North. Shōdanshima receives a large amount of yearly rainfall, giving rise to the region's thick jungles. These are dangerous places inhabited by creatures known as {@i yōkai}—preternatural creatures of both auspicious and calamitous portent.

While the {@i yōkai} are at present the greatest threat to life that a Seiganese citizen may face, this has not always been the case. The land of Seigai is contested by the eight dragon {@i daimyō} who have spent most of the last four-hundred years at war. Now that there is a {@i shōgun} with clear authority again, a window of flourishing and entrepreneurship has presented itself. How long the peace will last, well, one cannot say.
Seigai's shape may be familiar to you—it is based on a mirror-image of the nation of Croatia.

entries.name: Language
entries: You will be hard-pressed to find an individual who speaks the language known as Common on the streets of the capital Kōtoshi. The equivalent language for the citizens of Seigai is Draconic. Seigai Draconic has its own writing system, where each glyph describes a consonant-vowel pair (known as a {@i kana}). Some of the consonant-vowel sounds in the Common language are unused in Draconic. It may be easiest to present a table* of the available {@i kana}, so you can see what I mean.

entries.caption: Seigai Draconic Script
footnotes: * This table has been created for a foreign audience, and as such some characters have been moved from their proper spots for simplicity of understanding.

entries.name: Pronunciation Guide
entries: Seigai Draconic Vowels have a consistent pronunciation:

entries.name: Other Languages
entries: There are other languages spoken in various pockets of Seigai, such as Shīsā (among the {@race halfling (bunagaya)|KGtSeigai|bunagaya}) and Kuma (among the humans and {@race dwarf (korpokkur)|KGtSeigai|korpokkur} of Rep-un-Mosir).

Seigai Draconic script uses a real orthography from Japanese known as {@i katakana}. {@i Katakana} is used in Japanese for loan words from other languages and is one of four scripts, the other three being {@i hiragana}, {@i kanji}, and {@i romaji}.
In Japanese, some vowel sounds are extended, rendered in {@i katakana} as a long dash after the {@i kana} (ー). This is written in {@i romaji} with a dash ("macron") over the vowel (ā, ī, ū, ē, ō).

data.name: History of Seigai
entries: There are many tales contained in the {@i Records of Ancient Matters}, which I need not repeat here. However I include the events below as they are formative tales in the history of Seigai, and if you believe the discourse, explain the origins of Seigai's present governing structure.

entries.name: Setsuritsu Era
entries: {@b {@i The Founding Era.}} Deep in the sea of time, the creator {@i kami} (see {@book Religion|KGtSeigai|4|Religion}) gave birth to {@deity Shōjō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} and {@deity Shōdan-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}. The two were given an instruction to solidify and shape the earth, which they did hence with water dripped from a jeweled spear. Following this they birthed between them the many {@i kami} that make up the {@table Table of Prominent Kami|KGtSeigai|Seigai pantheon}, including the Three Precious Children: {@deity Tenshō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai|Tenshō-sama (Heaven-Shining-Great-August-Deity)}, {@deity Ran-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai|Ran-sama (His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness)}, and {@deity Tsuki-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai|Tsuki-sama (His Augustness, Moon-Night Possessor)}. The next tale concerns the former two.

Following a wager, Ran-sama was thrown out of heaven for gloating over Tenshō-sama with such violence that she retired in anger, plunging the world into darkness. His wandering led him into an encounter with Chinushi-sama, the eight-headed and eight-tailed dragon-serpent. This passage is presented as it occurs in the sacred texts of the Seigai people, edited for brevity and clarity.

[...] [His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness] descended to a place [called] Tori-kami at the head-waters of the River Hi in the Land of Ijumo. At this time some chopsticks came floating down the stream. So His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness, thinking that there must be people at the head-waters of the river, went up it in quest of them, when he came upon an old man and an old woman, two of them, who had a young girl between them, and were weeping. [...] [His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness] asked: "What is the cause of your crying?"

[The old man answered] saying: "I originally had eight young girls as daughters. But the eight-forked serpent of Koshi has come every year and devoured [one], and it is now its time to come, wherefore we weep."
Then he asked him: "What is its form like?"

[The old man] answered, saying: "Its eyes are like winter cherries, it has one body with eight heads and eight tails. Moreover on its body grows moss, and also hinoki and sugi. Its length extends over eight valleys and eight hills, and if one looks at its belly, it is all constantly bloody and inflamed."

[...] So His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness, at once taking and changing the young girl into a multitudinous and close-toothed comb which he stuck into his august hair-bunch, said to the Deities Foot-Stroking-Elder and Hand-Stroking-Elder: "Do you distill some eight-fold refined liquor? Also make a fence round about, in that fence make eight gates, at each gate tie [together] eight platforms, on each platform put a liquor-vat, and into each vat pour the eight-fold refined liquor, and wait."

So as they waited after having thus prepared everything in accordance with his bidding, the eight-forked serpent came truly as [the old man] had said, and immediately dipped a head into each vat, and drank the liquor. Thereupon it was intoxicated with drinking, and all [the heads] lay down and slept. Then His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness drew the ten-grasp blade, that was augustly girded on him, and cut the serpent in pieces, so that the River Hi flowed on, changed into a river of blood.

However Chinushi-sama's severed heads continued on living, impelled by malice and madness, until each head regrew a body, spawning the eight {@i chinushi-zu} (Chinushi-sama's Heads). Their names were Ieyasu, Kenshin, Motonari, Nobunaga, Shingen, Tatsuoki, Ujiyasu, and Yoshikage.

The {@i chinushi-zu} quickly began bickering, so they say, and so Tenshō-sama summoned Suinushi-sama, the dragon god of the sea, to corral the {@i chinushi-zu} and lead them away from chaos and destruction. Suinushi-sama was granted the Heavenly Sword, which had been discovered by Ran-sama in the tail of Chinushi-sama, and by wielding this artifact the {@i chinushi-zu} were frightened of Suinushi-sama and became reverent of him. Thus Suinushi-sama became the Dragon Emperor of land and sea.

Following this the {@i chinushi-zu} disappeared for a while from the written record. However, for reasons that will become clear later, it is believed they passed into the shadowy land of the dead, known as Yomi.

The story of Susano'o (Ran-sama) slaying the eightheaded dragon Yamata-no-Orochi (Chinushi-sama) is a myth recorded in the {@i Kojiki} ("Records of Ancient Matters"), one of two formative texts for the nation of Japan and the foundation of Shinto. The {@i Kojiki} was written by Ō no Yasumaro in the 8th century. Further narrative additions concerning the fate of Chinushi-sama's heads are invented for Seigai.

entries.name: Chokuzoku Era (CH1-745)
entries: {@b {@i The Era of Direct Control.}} During this era, Suinushi-sama governed as Emperor, overseeing the prosperity of Seigai. Art, culture, and religious practice flourished under his rule. Whenever his authority was questioned, Emperor Suinushi-sama brandished the Heavenly Sword, and quelled the insurrection.

While this is widely looked back upon as a Golden Era by the Seiganese, this would ignore the poor working conditions of the {@i nōmin} (see {@book Hierarchy|KGtSeigai|4|Hierarchy}) and the unbalanced wealth distribution towards the landowners. The Dragon Emperor was characteristically indifferent about such injustices, and spent most of the later years of the Chokuzoku Era flitting between the capital and his underwater palace Ryūgū-jō, leaving such bureaucracy in the hands of equally indifferent officials, as his home was the ocean and Emperor Suinushi-sama could not bear the land for long.

entries.name: Shigon Era (SH1-383)
entries: {@b {@i The Era of Given Authority.}} At the end of the Chokuzoku Era, the governance of Seigai passed from Suinushi-sama to the {@i chinushi-zu} almost overnight. This was presented to the Seiganese as a "well-earned retirement" for Suinushi-sama. The truth is kept from the populace so as not to create anti-shogunate sentiment. It took much research to gather a full sequence of events, and I present it to you below.

There was a powerful {@i oni} demon by the name of Oniō-sama who lived in the mountains North-East of Kōtoshi. Oniō-sama was a child of Chinushi-sama, born long before Chinushi-sama was defeated by Ran-sama. Over the centuries, Oniō-sama grew in power and ambition, and longed to replace Suinushi-sama as the Emperor of Seigai. He gathered unto himself a clan of {@i oni} and {@i yōkai} both fearsome and mighty, and began a campaign of terror against the citizens of Kōtoshi.

Emperor Suinushi-sama called together his own band of warriors and lent them the Heavenly Sword with which to slay Oniō-sama and end the insurrection. Knowing Oniō-sama had a weakness for alcohol just like his father, the Emperor also provided a flask of poisoned sake with which to render Oniō-sama incapacitated.

The warriors disguised themselves as monks and allowed themselves to be captured. While in custody, they appealed to the Oni-King's hospitality, suggesting an evening of frivolity and drinking. As the night grew late, the warrior Raikō offered Oniō-sama the poisoned flask, of which he drank.

As the poison set in, Oniō-sama fell into a deep slumber, and his true appearance was unveiled: limbs the size of tree trunks; fifteen eyes adorned his five-horned head; his torso was brick-red and he had limbs of yellow, blue, black, and white.

Raikō augustly unsheathed the Heavenly Sword and sliced off Oniō-sama's head. However, like his father Chinushi-sama, the rage and malice flowing through Oniō-sama gave his severed head supernatural vitality, and he promptly grasped upon the Heavenly Sword with his giant teeth and shattered it into shards.

With this final act, the Oni-King achieved a frightful terror; the heads of his father Chinushi-sama were no longer bound by fear of the sword, and at once they burst forth from Yomi, the land of the dead, where they had been held. At this news, the Emperor fled East to his palace in the sea, where he resides to this day.

The newly freed {@i chinushi-zu} began to divide the land up among themselves, and soon realized that without symbolic authority, their rule would be met with resistance. This authority they claimed by retaining the institution of Emperor, which Suinushi-sama still symbolically holds. They left the capital Kōtoshi and its surrounding lands vacant.

Their centuries-long exile in Yomi had done little to temper the bickering and in-fighting between the heads, and almost as soon as they claimed dominion over Seigai as {@i daimyō}, the border disputes began. Seiganese of low social status were forced to fight for their {@i daimyō} and paid the highest price in these pointless wars.

Three-hundred years of ubiquitous chaos ensued. The land was rent and torn; crops failed; evil {@i yōkai} emerged from the forgotten places and fed on the bodies of the fallen; and most of all no-one felt safe.

During this period, whichever of Chinushi-sama's heads had the most military might at any point claimed the title of {@i shōgun}, the de-facto leader of Seigai. The title changed hands many times, and the cyclical pattern was only finally interrupted by outside influence. When the {@i shōgun} Chinushi Nobunaga of Gunjinban established a trading relationship with a nearby nation and imported large quantities of the matchlock rifle, this delivered a martial advantage to his whole army that had only been achievable through magic up to this point. Chinushi Nobunaga exploited this advantage mercilessly and soon had the other seven {@i daimyō} subdued. Chinushi Nobunaga now controlled the only land-route to the capital and fiercely guarded it with his army of gunners.

To stamp his authority, Chinushi Nobunaga obtained (and most likely faked) a decree from Suinushi-sama to establish a political police force named the Azure Guard, which would be present in every city in Seigai, and loyal to the {@i shōgun}. For the last twenty years, this peace has held—mostly.

The tale of the slaying of Shuten-dōji (Oniō-sama) is taken from Japanese folklore, with a few alterations for Seigai. The earliest version of the tale is found in a picture scroll named {@i Ōeyama Ekotoba}, created in the 14th century. In the real myth, Watatsumi (Suinushi-sama) and Orochi (Chinushi-sama) do not feature (although there is a version of the tale where Orochi is indeed the father of Shuten-dōji); instead the emperor is Ichijō, and he does not bestow the warriors with the Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi (Heavenly Sword) for the deed.

data.name: Seiganese Society
entries: The people of Seigai are known as the {@i seigaijin}, or Seiganese people. It is an overly simplistic taxonomy; in truth there are many "societies" within Seigai. For now, I will speak broadly, else I shall be old and bald before I finish.

Firstly, it is worth noting the racial composition of the Seigai society. There is some variance depending on whether you find yourself in Shōjōshima or Shōdanshima, but you will generally find over half of the population consisting of {@race human|phb|humans}, followed in order of decreasing prevalence: {@race ryūson|KGtSeigai} (humanoid descendants of the {@i ō-ryū}), {@race shapechanger|KGtSeigai|shapechangers}, {@race kappa|KGtSeigai} (tortoise-like creatures), {@race masaru|KGtSeigai} (intelligent macaques), {@race halfling (bunagaya)|KGtSeigai|bunagaya} (orange-haired halflings), and {@race dwarf (korpokkur)|KGtSeigai|korpokkur} (butterbur dwarves). These seven are known as the {@i shichijin}.

In rural regions, beings of the same race often do cluster together in order to maintain their traditions (as carrying the torch is one of the tenets of Seigai religion). Meanwhile, urban areas are hotspots of cultural exchange. One of the quirks of the {@i shōgun's} recent decree that travelers must register at checkpoints during their journey has increased this all the more, as farmers are able to take advantage of foot traffic at these checkpoints to increase their trade. Merchants no longer have to travel into remote areas to make connections; as their trade has grown, they have also grown in power. A merchant group known as Shōnin-ikki has emerged, uniting many merchants under a single banner.

In spite of these new freedoms, everyday life in Seigai is still conducted under the watchful eye of the Azure Guard, the police force of Seigai. The Azure are hard to miss, dressed in their pearlescent blue armor. Anyone can "take up the blue" as they say, and join the ranks of the Azure Guard. It is a popular career path for the descendants of conscripts who spent their whole life fighting for their {@i daimyō}.

In addition to the {@i Records of Ancient Matters}, tales of ghost stories, known as {@i kaidan}, are popular among the Seiganese. These precautionary tales are essential lore in Seigai, which can be a dangerous place to live, especially in Shōdanshima if you were to wander outside the safe walls of the checkpoints and towns. It is far safer to travel by sea, but even this is fraught with peril as many {@i yōkai} hide in the depths. Rather than send the valuable Azure to patrol these roads, well-paying contracts are available to capable individuals. Each contract usually requires some proof that a threat has been dealt with, for instance some kind of trophy from a hostile creature. (On some rare occasions, a member of the Azure, or even a {@i samurai}, may join to observe the contract's fulfilment.) Those who undertake these contracts are typically referred to as the {@i rōnin} (see {@book The Life of a Rōnin: Mercenaries|KGtSeigai|6|Mercenaries}).

{@i Rōnin} are paid from the coffers of whatever {@i daimyō} governs the prefecture. (An official once noted to me that, in their opinion, every {@i daimyō} is more than capable of dealing with many of the local threats themselves, as they are dragons of incredible power. The contracts are merely a diversion to give the {@i rōnin} an external foe so that their gaze does not point upwards. This example points to both the cunning and the laziness of the {@i chinushi-zu}.)

The {@i daimyō} will go to any length to present the veneer of stability, peace, and harmony. Those with longer memories will tell you all about the centuries of jealousy and in-fighting that preceded this present truce. The conflict between Daizeihan and Tagūhan is an anachronism; typically of late, rival {@i daimyō} have been known to employ {@i rōnin} for missions of sabotage and espionage, thereby washing their hands of any accountability. These missions are reserved for only the most trusted of {@i rōnin}, but I am told the rewards are quite generous.
In feudal Japan, a {@i rōnin} was simply a {@i samurai} without a master. In Seigai, the term is used to mean any wandering mercenary.

As alluded to a moment ago, the eight {@i daimyō} are all dragons of the {@i chiryū} species, which is one of five categories of dragon in Seigai, known as the {@i ō-ryū} (see {@book Yōkai Index|KGtSeigai|8|Yōkai Index}). The highest of the {@i daimyō} is the the {@i shōgun}, who commands the loyalty of the Azure Guard, enforcing the peace through his military power.

Despite his strong-arm dictatorship, the peace enforced by Chinushi Nobunaga is a far better state-of-affairs than the centuries of war that preceded it. The optimism and lightheartedness of the people is hardly quashed, and can be observed during the numerous festivals throughout the year. An excuse to celebrate and remember those who fought for the present peace can always be found.

As a whole, the Seiganese people value three things above everything else: to always do your best, to consider others, and to keep improving. We each reflect on our contribution to the whole, and are generous with what we have, which in turn raises our morale. Put simply, in Seigai there is beauty to be found round every corner.

entries.name: Regions
entries: Seigai is separated into nine domains or {@i han}, each ruled by a {@i daimyō} (except for Kōtoban). A prefecture's name is usually related to the largest city within it.

entries.name: Akugakuhan
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Tatsuoki}

Akugakuhan is a small prefecture in northern Shōdanshima, nestled on the western side of Seigai's Teeth. The mountain wall extends high into the clouds, limiting the number of viable travel routes into the prefecture. It is believed the last drip to fall from {@deity Shōdan-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai|Shōdan-sama's} spear landed on the area now known as Akugakuhan, creating a large crown. Jealous of the crown, {@deity Shōjō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} took half of it, and created the Entei mountains.

entries.name: Akugaku ("Clenched Jaw")
entries: Many attempts have been made over the centuries to assail the city of Akugaku, however thanks to the limited access to the city only via the mountain passes or across the sea, Akugaku has never been captured.

entries.name: Bōfūhan
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Motonari}

Bōfūhan is a small prefecture located on Seigai's nose, on the North-Western tip of Shōjōshima. It is unfortunate that Bōfūhan has the ambitious Daizeihan as its neighbor; the {@i daimyō} Chinushi Motonari has seen his land's border relentlessly consumed over the centuries of war.

In spite of its vanishing size, Bōfūhan is the gateway to Seigai for foreign arrivals, and remains a highly important prefecture. The merchant alliance {@book Shōnin-ikki|KGtSeigai|4|Shōnin-ikki} has a large presence in its harbors.

entries.name: Bōfūshi ("City of Fleeting Wind")
entries: A harbor city, and where this author calls home. The winds here pick up in the early afternoon and die down by the next morning, like clockwork.

entries.name: Chōhan
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Ujiyasu}

Fish plays an instrumental role in the diet of the Seiganese people, nowhere more so than in the Chōhan region. After Daizeihan swallowed up the rice farms of Seiden, the significance of fish in Chōhan altered from one of taste to one of necessity. Even now in this new era of open trade, Chōhan has retained a feeling of autonomy by continuing to invest heavily in its fishing industry.

Ancient ruins of the Founding Era are scattered across the plains of Chōhan. While our modern buildings are constructed from wood by skilled carpenters, these relics are built from stone and decorated with intricate carved patterns. It is thought they survived Mount Yamabi's greatest eruption on the Day of Fire, while all other structures were burned away.

entries.name: Chōshi ("City of Fishing")
entries: Famous for its fish markets, it is said that the smell of Chōshi is so strong that it "keeps Shōjō-sama from opening her windows" (by this the Seiganese mean the eruption of Mount Yamabi).

entries.name: Daizeihan
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Kenshin}

While the other six vassal {@i daimyō} have kept mostly in line with the {@i shōgun's} rule, Kenshin is the one obstinate sibling who has done their best to resist the {@i shōgun's} policies. Daizeihan is the largest prefecture, mostly due to Kenshin's expansion ambitions. This is the source of the present quarrel with Tagūhan—who owns the land on the East bank of the River Zaikara.

Daizeihan is bisected from East to South-West by the outstretched arm of the Entei mountains. The Northern half has long stretches of rolling hills and fertile soil, while in the Southern half you will find mostly rocks and shrubs, especially as you journey further Westwards from Daizei.

entries.name: Daizei ("Great Military Strength")
entries: Regrettably, a place of much conflict. You will stick out like a sore thumb here if you are not in the Military. I would advise skipping Daizei entirely.

entries.name: Honzaishi ("Catfish's Fortune City")
entries: The {@i Records of Ancient Matters} state that Honzaishi was founded after a man fishing on the banks of the river discovered a catfish with a gold coin in its mouth.
Honzaishi is home to many bathhouses. Famous for their love of a dip in warm water, you can find the largest {@race masaru|KGtSeigai} population outside of Shōdanshima in Honzaishi.

entries.name: Seiden ("Prosperous Rice Paddies")
entries: The most exquisite views of the Entei mountain range are to be found in Seiden. How the farmers concentrate on their labor with such a vista I shall never know.

entries.name: Enfūhan
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Yoshikage}

At the very end of the Wanion Road is Enfūhan. This prefecture is similar to Bofūhan in many ways; both are located at the extremities, experience regular strong winds, and are underpopulated in comparison to the other prefectures. Enfūhan however is much larger and more mountainous, with great expanses of rainforest.

The {@i shōgun} sends fewer Azure soldiers down to Enfūhan; as such many of the more criminal elements of Seiganese society are conducted here, and the dissemination of {@i rōnin} contracts is more haphazardly conducted. Fearsome {@i yōkai} prowl through the forests with little resistance.

entries.name: Enfūshi ("Distant Wind City")
entries: Also known as Ikidomari ("The End of the Road"). This city is prone to extreme humidity and frequent tropical storms.

entries.name: Gunjinban
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Nobunaga (shōgun)}

Gunjinban is located at the hinge of the jaw of Seigai. By taking the strategic land-bridges to Kakyō and Kōtoshi, Chinushi Nobunaga solidified his vice-grip on the nation, and his rise to {@i shōgun} shortly followed. For his victory, Nobunaga's own province was left as a barren, flattened waste. For him, this was no matter; he had the entire nation and all its production under his control.

For the {@i nōmin} of Gunjinban, there was nothing else to cultivate than fields of ash and bodies. However, it is said {@deity Yōnō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} is the most productive of the {@i kami}, and from this cracked wasteland, green shoots are slowly emerging.

entries.name: Gunjin ("Military Encampment")
entries: Situated on the neck. For centuries Gunjin was a simple historical village, however in recent years it became a military outpost and grew in size exponentially, now becoming the seat of power for the whole nation.

entries.name: Kakyō ("Straddling Bridge")
entries: The city of the bridge. Ironically, there is no bridge to speak of. A prosperous market city as it is the point of intersection of three roads.

entries.name: Kōtoban
entries: Kōtoban is designated as the neutral territory of Seigai, separate from all of the power struggles outside its borders. This is viewed as a sacred institution; as such, the border crossing consists of a two-mile stretch of large {@i torii} gates named Tatorīmon, marking the transition from profane to the sacred. Tatorīmon was built at the beginning of the Shigon Era.

Before passing under the gates, travelers must wash their hands and mouth in the ceremonial fountains, even galloping horsemen on urgent business. It is said when Chinushi Nobunaga took the office of {@i shōgun}, he passed through the gates in his natural dragon form as a display of his power and control.

entries.name: Kōtoshi ("Official Capital City")
entries: The capital city of Seigai, and the home of the Great Azure Palace, where the Dragon Emperor resides—in theory. Kōtoshi is located at the "neck" of Seigai in the shade of Mount Tosaka. It is underpopulated considering its sprawl and renowned for its clean streets and strict policing.

entries.name: Rep-un-Mosir
entries: While not officially absorbed into Seigai, Rep-un-Mosir is considered a Seiganese state as an unincorporated territory. This island chain grew out of the ocean; some say {@deity Kanushi-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} flew near the water here and burned the sea away. Here you will find a small population of humans and {@race dwarf (korpokkur)|KGtSeigai|korpokkur}, hardy enough to stand the biting sea-spray and the ever-present threat of volcanic eruption. They speak their own language called {@language Kuma|KGtSeigai}.

entries.name: Ryūgū-jō
entries: The island district of Ryūgū-jō is where the Dragon Emperor resides. There are a small number of citizens who live here and on the surrounding islands. The area is patroled heavily by the {@i shōgun's} ships, ostensibly for the Dragon Emperor's "protection".

entries.name: Shikaban
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Shingen}

While Shikaban appears large, much of it is uninhabitable rainforest. A hundred years ago, Chinushi Shingen ordered a large swathe of land be deforested to make room for more farmland. This initiative was soon abandoned after the {@i yōkai} inhabiting the forest made their opinions on the matter clear. If you meet a {@i yōkai} armed with an axe in these forests, you can be sure where they got it from.

Shikaban also owns the series of islands on the Southern coast of Shōdanshima, which are named Shikahan-shotō, meaning "dapples of the deer". These were won from Enfūhan in one of the longest border wars of the Shigon era, and are home to the {@race halfling (bunagaya)|KGtSeigai|bunagaya} race.

entries.name: Shikashi ("City of Deer")
entries: The safe harbor of Shōdanshima. The streets of Shikashi are home to many deer. Folktales state this is due to the evil forces in the forests outside the city walls.

entries.name: Tagūhan
entries: {@i Daimyō: Chinushi Ieyasu}

Tagūhan is one of the last two warring prefectures in Seigai, although this is mostly a defensive posture. Daizeihan has made many efforts to challenge Tagūhan's Western border as Tagūhan holds territory that would cut the journey-length between Daizei and Honzaishi by a week. This conflict has not yet been reined in by the {@i shōgun}, which serves to propagate a rumor that the {@i shōgun} somehow benefits from it.

Elsewhere in Northern Tagūhan, there is a large forest named Ikimori. In the Setsuritsu Era, there was a colossal statue of {@deity Shōjō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} in this forest. One day there was a large earthquake, and the statue of Shōjō-sama was swallowed up by the soil, leaving only her headpiece, which can still be found today. During particularly rainy periods, the ground is sometimes seen to move up and down as if the avatar of Shōjō-sama is breathing, giving the forest its name: Ikimori, meaning "Breathing Forest".

entries.name: Tagūshi ("City of Many Shrines")
entries: The most reliable and safest route into the port of Akugaku, via ferry. As the name suggests, Tagūshi is the religious capital of Seigai.

entries.name: Nō Gakkō Theatre
entries: Many of the {@i kaidan} stories are taught among the Seiganese through dramatization. The Nō Gakkō is the largest school of actors and bards in the land.

entries.name: The Monks of Budō
entries: The Monks of Budō are the leaders of martial arts and self-improvement through spiritual practice. Each school has a figurehead called a {@i sensei} who typically resides in a remote location. Finding the {@i sensei} is an achievement in itself. In fact, there are stories of monks who have hidden themselves away so well that they are never found by a single pupil, wasting their entire life's work. Quite extraordinary.

entries.name: Onna-Bugeisha
entries: The most famous {@i rōnin} group is known as the Onna-Bugeisha, a team made up entirely of highly skilled women. When the {@i gashadokuro} (great skeleton) rose from the battlefield of Manshi, given life by the cacophony of wails, it was the Onna-Bugeisha who rose to face the colossal being, saving Kōtoshi from destruction.

entries.name: The Sacred Sound
entries: There is a great reverence for the power of words and sounds in Seigai; as such, all kinds of {@i madōshi} seek furtherance of their oratory skills in the company of the Sacred Sound, a magic college with campuses all across the land.

entries.name: Shinobi
entries: Those who prey in the night. Every nation has their clandestine cabals, and Seigai is no exception. The {@i shinobi} are often viewed as the shadow side of the {@i rōnin}, and can be fiercely loyal to their {@i daimyō}.

entries.name: Shōnin-ikki
entries: If there is any power to rival the {@i shōgun}, it is the Shōnin-ikki merchant alliance. The familiar red seahorse crest adorns the sails of most trading vessels in Seigai. Their recent emergence occurred as a response to the increasing disfavor towards the merchant class.

entries.name: The Way of Warriors
entries: Those who aspire to the ways of the {@i samurai} will most likely take schooling with the Way of Warriors. This faction is run by {@i samurai} and focuses on training civilians with noble warrior ideals—at a profit, of course.

entries.name: Hierarchy
entries: Seigai operates under a simple feudal system.

entries.name: Emperor
entries: At the very top of the chain is the Emperor, or to use his full title, His-Most-Dreadful-the-Great-Dragon-God-Emperor-certified-sovereign-who-rules-all-under-heaven, typically shortened to Dragon Emperor. Suinushi-sama has occupied this role for the past thousand years, and it is now merely ceremonial as he has no remaining power over the {@i daimyō}.

entries.name: Shōgun
entries: Below the Emperor is Chinushi Nobunaga, who is the {@i shōgun}. The {@i shōgun} is the most powerful of the {@i daimyō}, usually rising to power through conflict. However the office has not changed hands in the past twenty years despite the proliferation of firearms, as each {@i daimyō} knows that to challenge the {@i shōgun} and win would leave them with battle-weary forces and at the mercy of the other {@i daimyō}. An alliance would have to be made among multiple {@i daimyō} to challenge the {@i shōgun}, and alliances always create their own internal conflict.

entries.name: Daimyō
entries: Much has already been said about the {@i daimyō} in earlier chapters; however to summarize, there are eight {@i daimyō} (including the {@i shōgun}), each with a prefecture of Seigai under their jurisdiction. Together they are known as {@i chinushi-zu}, or "Chinushi-sama's Heads", and they are {@i chiryū} dragons. In theory, the role of {@i daimyō} is hereditary. I do not expect any of the {@i daimyō} intend on dying any time soon.

entries.name: Samurai
entries: The highest authority that a humanoid can aspire to in Seigai is to become a {@i samurai}. These skilled warriors are employed by the {@i daimyō} as their personal retainers, and once again, the role is hereditary. However, it has been known for the {@i daimyō} to employ headhunters to find gifted Azure soldiers and adopt them into the {@i samurai} class.

entries.name: Military
entries: A society that has spent the last four-hundred years at war will naturally confer privilege to those who fight in their name. As these wars have become less frequent, the armies of the {@i daimyō} have shrunk in size, and many soldiers have made the switch to join the ranks of the Azure Guard, which is the {@i shōgun's} police force. Whether in their {@i daimyō's} army or the Azure, there are many advantages to a military career, as it grants a generous pension, and the living costs of one's family are provided for.

entries.name: Nōmin
entries: The {@i nōmin} are the common people. They are not typically oppressed, although life is not often pleasant for the {@i nōmin}, especially if your prefecture is in conflict with another. During the height of the war, {@i nōmin} were expected to be loyal to their {@i daimyō} and answer the draft if necessary.

entries.name: Merchants
entries: The bottom rung of the ladder in Seigai belongs to the merchant class. Merchants are seen as unproductive and have increasingly faced stigma from the upper classes as Seigai rebuilds. In response to this discrimination, the merchants have begun to unite. The Shōnin-ikki alliance is now a visible presence on every street in Seigai.

entries.name: Religion
entries: The Seiganese people are known for their great piety and devotion, which they pay to the {@i kami}. The closest approximation in common to {@i kami} is "holy power". In our legends and tales, the first {@i kami} were created of themselves; these were manifestations of folds in the divine weave that links all things, each fold producing more folds and populating the pantheon of progenitor {@i kami} that we worship in Seigai today.

Nowadays, {@i kami} are generally not born but are elevated through the veneration of the people. Once an entity is sufficiently worshiped, it ceases to be {@i shichijin}, {@i yōkai}, beast, mountain, stream, or tree—and becomes {@i kami}.

In Seigai we have come to understand that we, having been made by the {@i kami}, share in their essence, as does the natural world. This essence is a spiritual substance known as {@i tama}, and exists in two forms: the gentle {@i tama}, and the assertive {@i tama}. They are separate agents within each spirit; however, despite their polarization, they coexist in harmony within all spiritual things. For example, when I experience compassion, I am experiencing my gentle {@i tama}, while hot anger or righteous indignation both demonstrate my assertive {@i tama} coming forth.

Like us, the {@i kami} are one spirit with multiple distinct {@i tama}. If you wisely treat a {@i kami} with respect and reverence, you will most likely encounter their {@i nigi-mitama}, the gentle soul. However, if you enter their numinous presence with ill-intent or haughtiness, you may rouse the {@i ara-mitama}, which would be quite foolish.

There are thousands of {@i kami}, and Seiganese folk will typically pray to whichever is most relevant, asking for such things as a favorable harvest, or a promotion, or even protection on a long journey. The clerics of Seigai may devote themselves to one {@i kami} or multiple.
Tribute to the {@i kami} is paid at a shrine. The entrance to these sacred spaces is always via a red or stone {@i torii} gate, which marks the transition from mundane to sacred.

On the next page I present a list of the most prominent {@i kami}. The {@i kami} can present as any gender, but their most common pronouns are listed alongside. Note the suffix {@i -sama} which is used as an honorific title for all {@i kami}.

entries.name: Godō
entries: During Suinushi-sama's reign, the Emperor invited many artists, scholars, and priests from other lands, who brought with them great insight, and later took back all that they had learned from the Seiganese people. New non-native ways of thinking about the {@i tama} and {@i kami} became prominent in this time, stressing the importance of personal revelation and spiritual ascent. This practice became known as Godō: the path to enlightenment.

When the {@i chinushi-zu} assumed control of Seigai, Godō practitioners found their autonomy under threat, and armed themselves to protect their interests. When a prominent priest suggested that even the {@i kami} were in need of enlightenment, the new {@i shōgun} Nobunaga took great offense and sent his armies to destroy all religions he deemed as "outside". The fighting was bloody, but in the end, the {@i shōgun's} army emerged victorious.

While the adherents of Godō are scattered, their architecture remains; many Godō temples have even been repurposed as shrines to the {@i kami}. A few rare Godō enclaves who sued for peace with the {@i shōgun} have been allowed to continue practising with strict oversight, now confined mostly to conducting funerary rites, for which they are in high demand.

entries.name: Magic
entries: A mother hears her baby's cries and she instinctively knows exactly what's wrong. A hermit imitates the shrieks of the kotengu in order to frighten bandits who may threaten his life. A shakuhachi player visits a decaying bamboo grove to hear the whistling of the North-East wind as it blows through. In Seigai, there is a magic inherent in each sound; this is known as {@i sonon}, meaning "sacred sound".

Magic-users in Seigai are capable individuals who have tapped into the potential of {@i sonon} in a variety of ways. Whether it is through an innate awareness, academic study, virtuosic talent, a connection to nature, or a gift from the {@i kami}, these individuals are able to create magical effects through their understanding of {@i sonon}. The sounds they create may be words, phrases, poems, or vocalizations created with the mouth, or perhaps a percussive clatter of steel against steel, the snapping of a branch, a plucked string, or a vibrating reed. In fact, Seiganese understanding is that it is more accurate to consider the "verbal" component of a spell as a "vibration" component.

As magic manifests in sounds in Seigai, the following spells require an additional vibration component for their casting: {@spell absorb elements|XGE}, {@spell beast sense}, {@spell catapult|XGE}, {@spell catnap|XGE}, {@spell control flames|XGE}, {@spell counterspell}, {@spell demiplane}, {@spell friends}, {@spell hypnotic pattern}, {@spell ice knife|XGE}, {@spell illusory dragon|XGE}, {@spell illusory script}, {@spell mental prison|XGE}, {@spell mind spike|XGE}, {@spell minor illusion}, {@spell mislead}, {@spell mold earth|XGE}, {@spell primal savagery|XGE}, {@spell psychic scream|XGE}, {@spell shape water|XGE}, {@spell snare|XGE}, {@spell steel wind strike|XGE}, {@spell thunderclap|XGE}, {@spell true strike}. (All other spells already have vibration components, and are therefore castable.)
{@i Sonon} is based on the Japanese idea of {@i kotodama}, the idea that magical power is contained in words and names, and therefore sounds.

data.name: Races
entries: Seigai is blessed with a number of its own unique native races. Some creatures formerly classed as {@i yōkai} have assimilated into society and live as part of the Seiganese with little tension. This transition occurred over many centuries as the humans and ryūson gradually grew to accept the assimilation of these races.

In the present era, the seven races of Seigai are known as the {@i shichijin}: {@race human|phb|humans}, {@race ryūson|KGtSeigai}, {@race masaru|KGtSeigai}, {@race shapechanger|KGtSeigai|shapechangers}, {@race halfling (bunagaya)|KGtSeigai|bunagaya}, {@race kappa|KGtSeigai}, and {@race dwarf (korpokkur)|KGtSeigai|korpokkur}. A visitor of another race will typically be met with curiosity. Do not mistake the wandering eyes for looks of judgement.
If you are not sure which race to choose for your character, you can roll on the table below.

entries.name: Bunagaya (Halfling Subrace)
entries: See the {@race halfling (bunagaya)|KGtSeigai|Bunagaya} entry.

entries.name: Half-Oni
entries: See the {@race Half-Oni|KGtSeigai} entry.

entries.name: Kappa (Tortle Variant)
entries: See the {@race Kappa|KGtSeigai} entry.

entries.name: Korpokkur (Dwarf Subrace)
entries: See the {@race dwarf (korpokkur)|KGtSeigai|Korpokkur} entry.
The {@i korpokkur} are distinct from European dwarf folklore, and are defined as a subrace for mechanical simplicity.

entries.name: Masaru
entries: See the {@race Masaru|KGtSeigai} entry.

While primates do carry some significance in Shinto and ancient Japanese literature, the {@i masaru} race are invented for Seigai. They are loosely based on the Japanese macaque, however, unlike the macaque, {@i masaru} have long tails.

entries.name: Ryūson (Dragonborn Variant)
entries: See the {@race Ryūson|KGtSeigai} entry.

entries.name: Shapechanger
entries: See the {@race Shapechanger|KGtSeigai} entry.

Raikō withdrew her sword and wiped it on the warrior's robes. The fight had been short. Even a well-skilled daitengu such as the one that lay sprawled out before her could stand little chance against the combined force of six {@i rōnin}. By the time the daitengu had realized he was outmatched, it was too late to call the many kotengu cowering in the cliffs above the temple to his aid. To think, his entire life training for this moment, only for it to be over so quickly. What a waste, Raikō thought.

She tentatively tiptoed down the claytiles of the roof and tossed the daitengu's polearm down below, where her companion Bisuda stood picking grime out from under his claws. As the naginata struck the stone ground, it clanged loudly, and Bisuda leapt into the air startled, landing on all four paws. Raikō let out a squeal of amusement. She had just learned that morning that Bisuda tended to overreact to loud noises, and she intended to use that information well, and often.

The journey up the mountains had been long and exhausting, but such things were to be expected when undertaking {@i rōnin} contracts. They had been sent to investigate strange reports coming from the villagers in the valley below: the bronze bell of the cliff-top temple was ringing in the dead of night. Not that unusual, except the temple was abandoned to the tengu; noone resided there any more.

As a {@i bushi}, a Seiganese warrior mercenary, she knew her inclusion on the mission meant that a violent outcome was highly probable. Apart from a few nuisance kotengu throwing rocks at them however, they had made it to the temple mostly unscathed. She had been beginning to feel shortchanged. She need not have worried.

It was not Raikō's first encounter with tengu by any means. The beaked and feathered humanoids were a common foe along the full extent of Shōdanshima. The daitengu she faced today however was a far more reclusive type. Unlike the kotengu, daitengu had smooth skin, and in place of the beak stood a long proud nose. Kotengu had to grasp their weapons in their talons in order to fly using their winged arms; daitengu meanwhile benefited from two large wings on their backs, leaving their hands free to wield a sword or polearm and, if needed, quickly retreat to an elevated position. This was exactly why Raikō now found herself on the temple roof.

The slaying of the daitengu did not however solve the mystery of the bell, and would not constitute the fulfilment of the contract. Raikō and her companions still had a job to complete, and she now turned her attention to the shōrō outbuilding, where the bell was housed. The primary purpose of the bonshō bell in Seigai was to call the monks to prayer. Bonshō were also designed to create powerful {@i sonon} auras when struck; these were known to frighten away evil {@i yōkai} and ward the temple.

Why, then, would a tengu want to strike the bell? Raikō turned the thought over in her mind, trying to make sense of it. Her companions Taba and the foreigner Faust had already begun to inspect the bell, and Raikō wandered over to join them. Taba picked up a nearby mallet and experimentally gave the bell a light tap. At once the air felt thick and heavy, the {@i sonon} waves pushing it around like an oar in the ocean. Faust pointed up, and the three of them craned their necks to gaze at a shadow in the beams above the bell.

All of a sudden, the ghost pounced. Raikō barely had time to draw her short wakizashi blade. She sliced instinctively as she threw herself on the ground, her sword swishing through the air, meeting no resistance. She felt her hackles raise as the cold ghostly form passed straight through her, and she lifted her head to see the figure walking away from the bell tower. The monk ghost barely walked ten paces before it faded.

Raikō's embarrassment quickly turned to disgust. She had not paid much attention to this before, but now her whiskers were touching the stone floor, she realised it was caked with bird droppings—as was her nice karuta armor. As she gingerly rose to her feet and brushed herself off, the answer came to her. The sun was rapidly descending below the mountaintops, and all that was left was to wait and see if her theory was correct.

Raikō spent the rest of the eveningpawing through the temple grounds searching for more clues with her five companions. Apart from evidence that the daitengu had lived here for a while, the search was beginning to feel like a waste of time. The benefit was that they had plenty of time to waste. At Raikō's insistence, the party had not yet reported the job as complete. It would be typical of the {@i daimyō's} office to cheat them out of their well-deserved pay, even though Raikō suspected slaying the daitengu would put an end to the nuisance. Still, she had doubts. The appearance of the monk ghost poked at the back of her mind. What caused it to linger here, rather than departing to Yomi, the land of the dead?

Her deep thought was suddenly interrupted by a ruckus at the shōrō. A great cloud of feathers began to cascade down from the ceiling, and Raikō began to wonder if a kotengu had managed to slip in unnoticed. She soon had her answer as from the loft of the shōrō descended a drove of dark-feathered doves who darted about, the whirring of their wings breaking the still night air. One pigeon was clearly disorientated as it flew head-first into the bell, and the cacophony was added to by a quiet thump, followed seconds later by a much louder one.

The quieter thump came as the pigeon fell to the ground and brushed itself off as if nothing had happened. The louder thump was caused by the corporealized corpse of the monk, sliding from the beams like a limp snake, now prostrate on the filthy tiles and slowly raising itself up onto its feet. Raikō and her companions watched as the monk made those same steps he had made earlier before he faded; this time, the hum of the bell was louder in Raikō's ears, and it seemed to give the monk ghost enough strength to hold onto whatever it was that was tethering him to the material plane.

In this form, the monk's body looked opaque enough to touch, and Raikō recalled the sensation as he had wafted over her earlier. Clever, she thought. He must have passed through the pigeons to spook them, every night for... how long? How terrible, that he spent so many years desperately trying to get the attention of the village below.

The monk led the party to the edge of the cliff and pointed at the forest below. It looked like some kind of rock-slide had occurred, but they were so high up, it was difficult to truly tell. Raikō realised they were going to have to climb down to get a better look. A foolish task in the middle of the night, but one thing Raikō had realised by working with these {@i rōnin}: foolishness gets you places.

Raikō let go of the kotengu's leg and prepared herself for the ground that was rushing up to meet her. She had been aiming for a patch of soft earth but, just as she shifted her body to release, the kotengu lurched sharply towards the cliffs. This was in no way ideal. Landing so close to the cliff wall would make it very difficult to break her fall with a roll. She had managed to disarm the kotengu mid-flight, but she knew it would be right on her as she landed, and if she got this wrong, she would be at the mercy of the kotengu's sharp talons.

She hit the ground hard and tried to soften the impact by rolling, but as she suspected her roll was interrupted by hard rock, and she felt the wind expelled from her lungs. The kotengu lunged downwards, claws outstretched. At the last second, Raikō withdrew into her fox form, becoming a much smaller target for the kotengu's clutches. Its claws scraped across the rock-face, leaving behind a set of sharp grooves across the surface. Raikō darted into the woods, still wheezing from the impact, while the kotengu attempted to work out how it had missed.

A few moments later, she heard the swoosh of an arrow and the thunk as it hit home, lodged in the kotengu's skull. Raikō emerged from the woods and stared up at her savior. The kappa Mafuke stood at the top of the cliff, bow in hand. He bowed in pride at his performance, and a little trickle of water dripped out from his skull, which Raikō traced with her eyes as it fell in the grey pre-dawn.

Her daring stunt had saved a great deal of time, which she now used to inspect the area where the monk had pointed. At first it seemed there was nothing but a pile of rocks. Now she was up close, the picture was much clearer. These rocks showed the signs of a sculptor, although it was difficult to make sense of how they fitted together.

The statue had clearly been jettisoned off the cliff, most likely by the tengu. No wonder the monk had such a strong tether to this world. This was a defilement of the highest offense. She wondered about the statue, and who it had represented. Strange though, she had not noticed any statues missing in the temple.

Of course. This statue was not from the temple building. Moreover, this was not one statue, but two. She picked through the stones until she found the face of the left lion-dog, shortly followed by the right. She had thought it strange that no lion-dogs had been tasked with guarding the temple. This is where they were, then. Two proud guardians, reduced to rubble.

She was joined a short while later by Rin the tanuki, who had found his own way down the cliff by fashioning a parachute out of god-knows-what. Rin and Raikō stood over the pieces and both knew there was little they could do. Maybe, if they could find the right pieces, Rin could go through mending the joins one-by-one. It would be tedious, and it would not necessarily restore the lion-dogs to life. However, it was their one shot at being paid for this job, and so Rin set to work while Raikō stood watch.

It was late in the morning by the time Rin announced he was finished. There before them both stood two majestic lion-dogs; on the left was the a-gyō with his open mouth, and on the right was the un-gyō, her jaw clenched. Cracks were evident over the entire surface of each statue, and Rin shrugged. Neither lion-dog showed much sign of life. Still, Rin came from the tradition of wandering priests known as {@i sō}, and he took a moment to consecrate the statues, satisfied that he had done all he could.

Raikō and Rin leisurely made their way back up to the temple to make their report. Raikō still held the magic slip of paper entrusted to the party by the {@i daimyō's} official. Whether she could remember the folds required to make it work was another matter. Hopefully someone in their party knew. And then, there was the tune you had to hum to bring it to life. How did it go again?

Raikō stopped. She was no closer to remembering the tune, but she had a much more pertinent revelation. She burst into a sprint, leaving Rin in her wake as he attempted to keep up in his cumbersome ō-yoroi armor. They were nearly at the temple, and she needed to know if her idea would work.

She ran straight past her party to the shōrō, and ignoring their questions, she lifted the hammer and struck the bell with all of her might. She felt the vibration course through her bones and she immediately let go of the hammer. As the deafening magic reverberated, translucent forms began to coalesce all around the temple. She paid them no mind. Her curiosity lay in what she might see over the edge of the cliff.
She peered down to the spot where she had landed earlier. Exactly as she had thought. The lion-dogs were gone.

Moments later, a fearsome beast, made of stone with gold cracks like lightning bolts painted across the surface, bounded forth and let out a mighty roar that seemed to increase the bell's intensity even further. A moment later, they were joined by another of the beasts, who joined in the chorus. Lastly, Rin followed behind, wiping his forehead and catching his breath.

The monk ghost appeared at Raikō's side, and with a smile, bowed deeply. He joined a procession of ghostly forms who made their way up the stone steps into the temple, each of them giving voice to a chant that had not been sung in this region for decades. At the gate, Raikō watched as the two great beasts found their posts and settled in place.
The guardians had returned.

entries.name: Mercenaries
entries: I have met many highly-skilled professionals in Seigai, who are known by the term {@i rōnin}. They are not a social class in and of themselves; they are typically {@i nōmin} (commoners), although I have heard of squads of {@i rōnin} captained by a {@i samurai}.

While martial skills can be extremely useful in this trade, they are not the only skills in high demand. To be officially recognized as a {@i rōnin}, you must obtain a professional license, of which there are four types: {@i bushi} (warriors), {@i madōshi} (mages), {@i bushi} (experts), and {@i sō} (priests). Licenses are granted by officials of the {@i shōgun} and require a letter of recommendation.

Certain assignments may specify that one or more professions must be represented in a questing party for their application to even be considered. Due to this, there is quite a black market for fake {@i rōnin} licenses.

entries.name: Armor
entries: In Seigai, the armor worn by {@i bushi} is typically of lamellar construction. Recently, to help protect the wearer against projectile weapons, new types of plate armor known as tosei have become popular; however these are not yet widely made.

data.name: Rumors
entries: I have heard many rumors during my travels around Seigai, some of which I have presented below as a window in the concerns of its citizens.

entries.name: Bird of Paradise
entries: It is said that if you spend the night at the abandoned temple of Kūkai-sama on Mt. Mani, you may hear the calls of the bird of paradise who resides only in the holiest of places. (See: {@i Ugetsu Monogatari} [1776])

entries.name: Bloodbath
entries: The springs that provide hot water to the famous {@i onsen} of Honzaishi have recently begun pouring with blood, leaving the town overrun with {@creature filthlicker|KGtSeigai|akaname (flitchlickers)}.

entries.name: Cephalopod Squad
entries: Since the migrant bunagaya population of Chōshi discovered {@i takoyaki}, the octopus fishing trade has been booming. However, fishing boats have started going missing. New hires are needed to meet the demand.

entries.name: Chiyome's Agents
entries: In Shikaban, a noblewoman has been recruiting women as covert ninja agents in service of the {@i daimyō}. Word on the street is that they are responsible for a recent high-profile assassination.

entries.name: The Curious Case at Seiden Gate
entries: After the murder of a {@i samurai}, four witnesses all have different tales of what took place. (See: {@i Rashōmon} [1950]).

entries.name: The Emperor's Sword
entries: No-one truly knows what came of the Heavenly Sword after it was shattered by Oniō-sama, but if the shards could be found the sword reforged, some suppose it would still hold power over the {@i chinushi-zu}. Though, to speak of such things would be treason.

entries.name: Final Nail in the Kofun
entries: The death of the village elder in Taihai means the kofun must be reopened. The spirits inside however are not at rest.

entries.name: Hell's Gate
entries: Recently, citizens paying respect at the shrine to Kōgaku-sama have gone missing. It seems once someone passes through the {@i torii} gate, they cross a threshold into a cursed realm.

entries.name: Heron Back Again
entries: A crane {@i kami} is searching for the woman who saved her life, so she can repay the favor with great fortune.

entries.name: Hōichi the Earless
entries: At the Akama Temple, there lives a blind biwa-player named Hōichi. While playing in the temple graveyard, Hōichi roused a {@i samurai} spirit who demanded Hōichi play every day for a thousand years. The priests wrote the Heart Sutra all over Hōichi's body to protect him from the spirit; however, they forgot to write on his ears. The spirit stole Hōichi's ears, and now he cannot hear himself play biwa. (See: {@i Kwaidan: Stories and Studies of Strange Things} [1904] by Lafcadio Hearn or the film {@i Kwaidan} [1964])

entries.name: Keep the Home Fires Burning
entries: In Rep-un-Mosir, residents have found themselves suddenly unable to keep their hearths lit. It seems something is wrong with Old Grandma Fire.

entries.name: Lady of the Snow
entries: Deep in the Entei mountains, a lumberjack has recently found out to his horror that he is married to a spirit, who has taken their son away.

entries.name: The Long Goodbye
entries: A young {@i chiryū} dragon has vacated her office and departed into the wilds. This has left the {@i shōgun} very angry.

entries.name: Long Night of the Ushi-Tora
entries: The town of Tsuyotake used to have a shrine at its North-East corner until it was destroyed in a fire. Since then, the {@i kimon} of Tsuyotake has been undefended, and {@i oni} descend upon the town every night, killing any citizens they find, and hampering any effort to ward the town. All the citizens need are three nights to repair their shrine.

entries.name: Manor of the Dishes
entries: A {@i samurai} is haunted by the ghost of a maidservant he killed for losing one of his ten fine plates. (See: {@i Banchō Sarayashiki})

entries.name: Mizaru, Kikazaru, Iwazaru
entries: The masaru village of San-en-mura has three elders who govern all legal proceedings. Getting them to agree on anything is quite impossible, especially as they each disregard one type of evidence.

entries.name: Night Parade of One Hundred Demons
entries: Every year in the late Summer, for one night the streets all around Seigai are filled with a parade of {@i oni} and {@i yōkai}, causing chaos and frightening the people. This year, the {@i shōgun} has decided this tradition must end, at all costs.

entries.name: Nō Way, Hosei
entries: The Nō Gakkō of Kōtoshi is short of performers and looking for bards to bolster their ranks. Bring your own mask.

entries.name: Oni Oh My
entries: The soybean crop in the village of Hachon has failed, leaving the villagers with no legumes for their onirepelling ceremony.

entries.name: Quibbling Rivalry
entries: Two villages with an ancient disagreement need assistance putting on a festival to appease a river {@i kami} who has caused a series of floods.

entries.name: Rogue Rōnin
entries: After failing to meet the terms of a contract, a team of {@i rōnin} has decided to deliver retribution on the {@i daimyō}, by sneaking into the city at night and assassinating prominent officials.

entries.name: Sound Reasoning
entries: A village has been spooked by the sound of a bronze bell ringing deep in the mountains, seemingly emanating from an abandoned temple. (See: {@book The Life of a Rōnin|KGtSeigai|6|The Life of a Rōnin})

entries.name: Starter for Zen
entries: A stone representing Mt. Yamabi in the famous rock garden of Kyōku has been stolen. No footprints were left behind in the gravel.

entries.name: Take Up the Blue
entries: A generous offer from the {@i shōgun} is announced across the realm: join the Azure Guard and your crimes against the state will be forgiven. The word around town is that Chinushi Nobunaga is recruiting for war abroad.

entries.name: Terror-Cotta
entries: The one-thousand clay soldier {@i haniwa} statues of Gunjin have suddenly and mysteriously come to life, and threaten the safety of the city and its inhabitants.

entries.name: Trash Pandas
entries: A tribe of peaceful tanuki has been persistently raided by tengu bandits in the foothills of the Entei mountains.

entries.name: Tremors in Mt. Yamabi
entries: Recently, the area around Mt. Yamabi has experienced a large amount of seismic activity. Fearing the worst, the {@i daimyō} of Chōhan has hatched a plan to appease the volcanic spirits.

entries.name: What a Wind-Up
entries: A playful wind has been leading travelers off the Wanion Road, never to be seen again.

entries.name: What's up Lion-Dog
entries: In Tagūshi, one of the lion-dog guardians of the shrine to Kaze-sama was destroyed by a fallen tree in a violent storm. The other lion-dog has gone missing as a result. Anyone who can track them down is promised a rich reward.

entries.name: What We Do in the Shadows
entries: The {@i shōgun} is looking for a highly skilled team of {@i shinobi} to break into the city of Akugaku. The mission: assassinate the {@i daimyō}.

data.name: Yōkai
entries: The Seiganese people use the word {@i yōkai} to refer to any creature that is neither one of the seven races of Seigai, nor a common beast. It may seem as if such a broad taxonomy is useless. On the contrary, the {@i yōkai} play a pivotal role in Seiganese culture.

Take the example of my dear friend Kuemo. When he lost a trade caravan to a gang of violent {@i garappa}, I heard him utter, "Such are the {@i yōkai}." Indeed this was one of his more often used phrases, even for situations when the source of malice was not so clear.
"Such are the {@i yōkai}," I heard him say again, as he lay dying in my arms from a sickness of the lungs.

From much contemplation, my best offer to you dear reader is that {@i yōkai} describes all that defies our attempts at explanation and mastery. With that in mind, I shall now embark on the foolish endeavor of attempting to catalog a number of the more distinct {@i yōkai}.

entries.name: Reskinning Monsters
entries: A number of creatures with characteristics similar to the {@i yōkai} of Seigai can be found among other compendia.
You can find excellent descriptions for the majority of the {@i yōkai} in the Reskinning Monsters table at {@link yokai.com}

entries.name: Appendix A: Shapechanger Subrace Template
entries: Although the five {@race shapechanger|KGtSeigai|bakemono} listed in this guide are the most well-known shapechanger {@i yōkai}, it is reasonable to assume that other creatures may become shapechangers after living a long life. One would imagine those shapechangers would assuming the following attributes:

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: An ability score of your choice increases by 1.

entries.name: Bakemono Magic
entries: You know a cantrip of your choice. When you reach 3rd level, you can choose a 1st-level spell and be able to cast it once at 2nd-level with this trait, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can choose a 2nd-level spell and be able to cast it once with this trait, regaining the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Beast Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

The ability to choose your ability score increases and innate spells is powerful and can easily make the game unbalanced. It is best to consult with your GM to ensure your shapechanger subrace is fair.

entries.name: Appendix B: Beasts in Seigai
entries: Travel along the Wanion Road in Shōdanshima and you are likely to come across a large variety of beasts. Below I present an incomplete list of the beasts that can be found in Seigai.

entries.name: Shapechanger Beast Forms
entries: These are the characteristics of some of the woodland creatures I have observed in Seigai.
Official statistics for the badger and cat have already been published by {@i Wizards Of The Coast} and are presented below.

These modern Japanese names were extracted from {@link Baby Names|https://babynames.com} on October 7th, 2020. Due to the sheer number, I haven't been able to confirm the accuracy of every meaning, so apologies for any errors.

entries.name: Appendix E: Playlists
entries: The following Spotify playlists are designed for Seigai, and feature music by Japanese composers.

entries.name: Appendix F: Recommended Media
entries: These books, films, podcasts, and whatever else were influential to me when making this guide, and I'd highly recommend checking them out!

items: {@i The Book of Hakutaku: A Bestiary of Japanese Monsters} (Matthew Meyer; 2019)
{@i The Hour of Meeting Evil Spirits: An Encyclopedia of Mononoke and Magic: 2} (Matthew Meyer; 2015)
{@i The Night Parade of One Hundred Demons: A Field Guide to Japanese Yokai} (Matthew Meyer; 2015)

{@i {@link Unbreakable Vol. 1|http://unbreakablerpg.com/}} (Jacky Leung, Jazz Eisinger, Anthony Alipio, Steve Huynh, Kat Kruger, Daniel Kwan, Keven Nguyen, Collette, Quach, KC Shi, Russ Wilde, Ethan Yen; 2020)
