{@link Warring States Japan: Sengoku Jidai|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hDsdkoln59A&list=PLhyKYa0YJ_5A649vEQk37316BH8FsaU24&ab_channel=ExtraCredits} (Extra History; 2014) [Educational Video Series]

deity.name: Shōjō-sama
deity.title: The Female-Who-Invites
entries: Among the first deities. With her husband {@deity Shōdan-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, created the land of Seigai, and birthed the rest of the {@i kami}.

deity.name: Shōdan-sama
deity.title: The Male-Who-Invites
entries: Among the first deities. With his wife {@deity Shōjō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, created the land of Seigai, and sired the rest of the {@i kami}.

deity.name: Tenshō-sama
deity.title: The Heavenly-Shining-Great-August-Deity
entries: The great goddess of the Sun, supreme among the deities. Tenshō-sama ordained Suinushi-sama as Emperor.

deity.name: Tsuki-sama
deity.title: Moon-Night Possessor
entries: A brother of {@deity Tenshō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, and governs the light of the moon. He and Tenshō-sama have an ancient quarrel, hence they are in different parts of the sky.

deity.name: Ran-sama
deity.title: His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness
entries: Another brother of {@deity Tenshō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, and also in conflict with her. Through his cunning, Ran-sama slew Chinushi-sama, giving rise to the {@i chinushi-zu}.

deity.name: Inga-sama
deity.title: Heavenly-Alarming-Female
entries: The goddess of the dawn and revelry. When {@deity Tenshō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} once went into hiding, Inga-sama made the other {@i kami} laugh so much that Tenshō-sama came out of hiding to see what the commotion was about.

deity.name: Kaze-sama
deity.title: The Prince-of-Long-Wind
entries: The god of the wind, and often paired with {@deity Kaminari-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} in holy places. Kaze-sama has a terrifying green-skinned appearance and carries a bag of wind around his shoulders.

deity.name: Kaminari-sama
deity.title: The Eight Thunder-Deities
entries: The god of storms, and often paired with {@deity Kaze-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai} in holy places. Kaminari-sama has a similarly terrifying appearance, and carries with him the taiko drums of thunder.

deity.name: Yōnō-sama
entries: The goddess of fertility and agriculture. Yōnō-sama has a close relationship with the kitsune, and is often depicted with a fox-like appearance. She is the most widely venerated {@i kami} in Seigai.

deity.name: Bushi-sama
deity.title: The Eight-Banners-Deity
entries: The divine protector of Seigai and the god of warriors. The Azure invoke Bushi-sama before going into battle.

deity.name: Kanushi-sama
deity.title: The Shining-Elder
entries: The {@i kami} of fire. The trauma of giving birth to Kanushi-sama killed {@deity Shōjō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, which sent her to the underworld.

deity.name: Sōbai-sama
deity.title: The Many-Minds'-Thought-Combining Deity
entries: Sōbai-sama is the great mediator, the most wise of the {@i kami}.

deity.name: Mizu-sama
entries: The guardian of pools, lakes, seas, and the ocean, and all who reside in them. Also the goddess of the sewers.

language.name: Seigai Draconic
entries: You will be hard-pressed to find an individual who speaks the language known as Common on the streets of the capital Kōtoshi. The equivalent language for the citizens of Seigai is Draconic. Seigai Draconic has its own writing system, where each glyph describes a consonant-vowel pair (known as a {@i kana}). Some of the consonant-vowel sounds in the Common language are unused in Draconic.

language.name: Shīsā
entries: The language spoken in Shikahan-shotō, and by the {@race halfling (bunagaya)|KGtSeigai|bunagaya} race.

language.name: Kuma
entries: The language spoken in Rep-un-Mosir, and by the {@race dwarf (korpokkur)|KGtSeigai|korpokkur} race. Its name means 'bear' in common.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern colors in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Fiend
entries: Your creature type is fiend, rather than humanoid.

entries.name: Oni's Legacy
entries: You can cast the {@spell primal savagery|XGE} cantrip, using Charisma as your spellcasting ability.

"A child that does not resemble its parents is the child of an {@i oni}." This common Seiganese expression is often used to chastise a child; however, for some individuals, this phrase takes on an all-too-real quality. Every so often, a child is born with red, blue, or green skin, along with two horns on their head and jet-black hair. This event is often associated with a curse placed on a family, but the child is rarely seen as a curse in and of themselves. In fact, the child is commonly seen as a sign of warding, keeping greater {@i oni} from terrorising their home.

A half-oni will differentiate themself from a pureblooded {@i oni} by wearing a talisman such as a necklace of holly leaves and dried sardine heads, or offering gifts of roasted soybeans; these are examples of things that regular {@i oni} cannot abide. Without this vital visual evidence that a half-oni is not an {@i oni}, they will usually find people avoid them in the street out of fear.

entries.name: Subraces
entries: In addition to the base racial traits of the half-oni, you have a racial heritage and gain attributes from that race according to the table below. You inherit the Speed, Size, and Language attributes from your parent race.

rows: Brave, Halfling Nimbleness, Limber, Net Positive
Home Is Where The Hearth Is, Skilled Potter
Animal Empathy, Forager, Light-Footed and Light-Tailed, Prehensile Tail

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Small.

entries.name: Speed
entries: You have a walking and swimming speed of 25 feet.

entries.name: Claws
entries: Your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you can deal slashing damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Dish Head
entries: Your head crests up into a small dish filled with water. While your head is filled with water, you have advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic. Whenever you fail a Dexterity saving throw, the bowl empties, and must be refilled to restore this ability. If you fail the Dexterity saving throw by 5 or more, the bowl empties completely, and you gain a point of {@condition exhaustion}, which can only be removed by refilling the bowl.

entries.name: Fey
entries: Your creature type is fey, rather than humanoid.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: Due to your shell and the shape of your body, you are ill-suited to wearing armor. Your shell provides ample protection, however; it gives you a base AC of 17 (your Dexterity modifier doesn't affect this number). You gain no benefit from wearing armor, but if you are using a shield, you can apply the shield's bonus as normal.

entries.name: Wellbeing
entries: Kappa have an intuitive knowledge of medicine, particularly the skill of setting broken bones. You have proficiency in the {@skill Medicine} skill.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and Aquan.

At first sight, one could easily be disgusted by a kappa. While they resemble the tortles of other lands, it is not difficult to see how they diverge: a shorter stature, webbed fingers and toes, a beak-like mouth with pointed teeth, but most disturbingly, a circular orifice in the top of their skull, giving access to a water-filled chamber where, by all rights, the brain should reside. It would be far too easy to dismiss these creatures as the product of darkness—but that would be an unfair judgement. Many kappa are quite wise, gentle creatures.

entries.name: Age
entries: Masaru typically live up to about 60 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Masaru range in size from 4 and a half to 5 and a half feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: You have a walking and climbing speed of 25 feet.

entries.name: Animal Empathy
entries: Whenever you make a Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check related to primates or tamed animal species, you are considered proficient in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Forager
entries: You have advantage on rolls for foraging for food.

entries.name: Light-Footed and Light-Tailed
entries: You have advantage on {@skill Stealth} rolls when you're at a higher elevation than the person/people trying to detect you.

entries.name: Prehensile Tail
entries: Your tail is dexterous enough to use basic tools, pick up objects, and hold you hanging from something. Your tail cannot wield weapons or a shield.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic}, and you can speak {@language primate|KGtSeigai}. Primate does not have a written language.

The masaru are a race of intelligent bipedal primates native to the jungles of Shōdanshima. They are typically curious and blunt creatures, full of impropriety. At the same time, they are known for their great bravery and loyalty.
Though the masaru and bunagaya hail from different regions in Seigai, it is said that whenever the two meet they tend to foster deep friendships.
If masaru have one vice, it is hot water. If you ever need to find a masaru, go check the nearest {@i onsen}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Ryūson live between 100 and 150 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your walking speed is 30 feet, and you have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Claws
entries: Your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you can deal slashed damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Draconic Ancestry
entries: You have draconic ancestry. Choose one type of dragon from the Draconic Ancestry table. Your ability score increase and Godai Spirit Powers are determined by the dragon type, as shown in the table.

entries.name: Godai Spirit
entries: You can cast the cantrip associated with your draconic ancestry at well. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the Seijin Spell associated with your draconic ancestry once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 11th level, you can cast the Teinen Spell associated with your draconic ancestry once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and one other language of your choice.

The dragonborn of Seigai are known as ryūson, taking after the {@i ō-ryū}, and have few elements in common with foreign dragonborn. Rather than tendrils, ryūson have soft hair. Their heads are more mammalian than reptilian and two horns protrude backwards from the rear of the skull. Male ryūson have long flowing whiskers and beards, while female ryūson have more modest horns, and longer serpentine tails. The scales of the ryūson change their color depending on the angle of the light.
Each ryūson has a lineage that can be traced back to one of the elder dragon {@i kami} of Seigai.

entries.name: Earth Dragonborn
entries: Earth dragonborn ({@i chison}) can trace their lineage back to the great eightforked serpent Chinushi-sama. They have a natural affinity with the ground beneath their feet. Their scales are a dusty tan color and their faces are more naturally frightening than other ryūson.

entries.name: Water Dragonborn
entries: Water dragonborn ({@i suison}) trace their ancestors back to the Dragon Emperor himself, Suinushi-sama. They are at one with the ocean, instinctively reacting to and flowing with the currents as they swim. Their tail is considerably longer than other ryūson.

entries.name: Fire Dragonborn
entries: Fire dragonborn ({@i kason}) are connected to the {@i kami} of fire, {@deity Kanushi-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, who himself was born from {@deity Shōjō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}, killing her in the process. Their skin color is coal-black. Their body temperature is warmer than other creatures—you would be wise not to offer your hand to a fire dragonborn without a protective glove.

entries.name: Air Dragonborn
entries: Air dragonborn ({@i fūson}) are descendants of the great dragon Fūnushi-sama of the rain and the snow, and feel quite at home in inclement weather.

entries.name: Void Dragonborn
entries: Void dragonborn ({@i kūson}) are tied to the great dragon protector of the night stars, Kūnushi-sama. They are just as much a part of the Ethereal Realm as the Material Plane. Their skin is deep indigo and they have silver hair.

entries.name: Size
entries: When in humanoid form, you are a Medium creature. When in anthropomorphic form, you are a Small creature.

entries.name: Speed
entries: When in humanoid or anthropomorphic form, your walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Fey
entries: Your creature type is fey, rather than humanoid.

entries.name: Bakemono
entries: You can use an action to shapeshift into your beast form, into a humanoid, or into an anthropomorphic (semi-humanoid) form halfway between the two. Your appearance in all three forms is hereditary just like any other race, and any equipment you wear in your human form adjusts to the size of your anthropomorphic form. When shifted into your beast form, the following rules apply:

items: Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the beast, but you retain your alignment, personality, hit points, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiences, in addition to gaining those of the beast. If the beast has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the beast's bonus instead of yours.

You can't cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn't break your concentration on a spell you've already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as {@spell call lightning|phb}, that you've already cast.

You retain the benefit of any features from your class or other sources and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as darkvision, unless your new form also has that sense.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature's shape and size. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have a nocturnal creature's keen senses, especially in the dark. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Limber
entries: You have a swimming speed of 25 feet and a climbing speed of 25 feet.

entries.name: Net Positive
entries: You have proficiency with {@item net|phb|nets}, and when making an attack with a net, you have advantage on the roll.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and {@language Shīsā|KGtSeigai}.

In the Shikahan-shotō region, the spirit of cooperation is a tradition held dear between humans and a race of halflings known as bunagaya, or {@i kijimunā} in the Shīsā tongue. The bunagaya may look like children, but while Seiganese individuals of other races will grow old and grey, bunagaya keep their youthful features and thick orange hair well into their later years. The bunagaya are coastal folk and gladly put this knowledge to good use by helping fisherfolk with their trade; with a bunagaya companion, you can always guarantee returning home with a bucketful of fish.

Bunagaya reside in the banyan trees of Shikahanshotō, creating complex networks of treehouses and hanging walkways. When away from home, most bunagaya are fairly restless until they can find an elevated position on which to sleep.
Another such peculiarity is the shared enmity between bunagaya and octopuses. This antagonism spans back generations and no-one can quite remember why it is that they dislike each other so much.

entries.name: Home Is Where The Hearth Is
entries: You know the {@spell mold earth|XGE} cantrip and can cast it at will. In addition, you can spend an hour crafting a korpokkur home large enough for 10 medium creatures, provided the ground is earth. A creature you completes a long rest inside this home gains temporary hit points equal to half their level rounded down (minimum 1). You can spend another hour to unmake the home, leaving no trace of you having been there.

entries.name: Skilled Potter
entries: You have proficiency with {@item potter's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and {@language Kuma|KGtSeigai}.

In the Ryūguchi Sea, there exists a small volcanic island chain known as Rep-un-Mosir in Kuma, which is the language spoken there. These islands are home to an indigenous race known as the korpokkur, meaning "people below the leaves of the butterbur plant".

The korpokkur stand two to three feet tall and, like the bunagaya, are skilled fisherfolk. However, the similarities end there. Rather than making their homes in the trees, the korpokkur prefer to construct elaborate pits with domed roofs made of the leaves of the butterbur plant, which offer much more protection from the strong winds that regularly tear through Rep-un-Mosir. The korpokkur place special importance on the homes they build, and revere the hearth as she is a {@i kami} that must be kept aflame, known as Grandma Fire.

Korpokkur are shy individuals, and prefer to remain unseen. Despite this, they have a good relationship with the humans who also occupy Rep-un-Mosir, frequently exchanging gifts under cover of darkness.
If a korpokkur has left Rep-un-Mosir, it is usually for an exceedingly good reason.

entries.name: Age
entries: Bakeneko have usually awakened by age 15 as an adult, and go on to live another 100 years on average.

entries.name: Bakeneko Magic
entries: You know the {@spell produce flame} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell feather fall} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell protection from poison} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Feline Agility
entries: Your reflexes and agility allows you to move with a burst of speed. When you move on your turn in combat, you can double your speed until the end of the turn. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you move 0 feet on one of your turns.

entries.name: Age
entries: Rivers are a dangerous place to make your home in Seigai, and provided a kawauso has not been eaten by a {@i suiko} or {@i garappa} by age 10, awakening is a foregone conclusion. They tend to live the shortest of the shapechangers, lasting around 80 years.

entries.name: Kawauso Magic
entries: You know the {@spell magic stone|XGE} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell command} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell calm emotions} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Mimicry
entries: You can mimic sounds you have heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds you make can tell they are imitations with a successful Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check opposed by your Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check.

entries.name: Age
entries: If a fox has reached the age of 5, it will almost certainly become a kitsune bakemono. Typically they awaken with infant minds, but kitsune go on to live long lives, gaining an extra tail every 100 years or so. At 900 years and 9 tails, a kitsune will ascend into a celestial form.

entries.name: Gifted Communicator
entries: You can speak, read, and write two languages of your choice.

entries.name: Kitsune Magic
entries: You know the {@spell dancing lights} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell sanctuary} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell sending} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Scoundrel
entries: You are proficient in the {@skill Deception} skill.

entries.name: Age
entries: Once a badger reaches the age of 13, the chance of it awakening into a mujina increases exponentially. They go on ot live around 250 years.

entries.name: Mujina Magic
entries: You know the {@spell shillelagh} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell alarm} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell locate animals or plants} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Out of Sight
entries: While in forest terrain, whenver you make a Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check, you are considered proficient in the {@skill Stealth} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Age
entries: A tanuki will typically awaken aroudn age 10, and live as a bakemono for another 200 years. However I have heard tales of tanuki who exceed this lifespan two- or even three-fold.

entries.name: Money Bags
entries: You make your money stretch further. Whenever you make a Charisma ({@skill Persuasian}) check to barter, you are considered proficient in the {@skill Persuasion} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Tanuki Magic
entries: You know the {@spell minor illusion} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell ceremony|XGE} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell phantasmal force} spell once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Wait A Minute
entries: Whenever you fail a {@skill Deception} or {@skill Performance} check, you can use your reaction to move half your movement speed, without incurring opportunity attacks.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Skill Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Small.

entries.name: Brave
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Halfling Nimbleness
entries: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

entries.name: Limber
entries: You have a swimming speed of 25 feet and a climbing speed of 25 feet.

entries.name: Net Positive
entries: You have proficiency with {@item net|phb|nets}, and when making an attack with a net, you have advantage on the roll.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and {@language Shīsā|KGtSeigai}.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Small.

entries.name: Speed
entries: You have a walking and swimming speed of 25 feet.

entries.name: Dish Head
entries: Your head crests up into a small dish filled with water. While your head is filled with water, you have advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against magic. Whenever you fail a Dexterity saving throw, the bowl empties, and must be refilled to restore this ability. If you fail the Dexterity saving throw by 5 or more, the bowl empties completely, and you gain a point of {@condition exhaustion}, which can only be removed by refilling the bowl.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: Due to your shell and the shape of your body, you are ill-suited to wearing armor. Your shell provides ample protection, however; it gives you a base AC of 17 (your Dexterity modifier doesn't affect this number). You gain no benefit from wearing armor, but if you are using a shield, you can apply the shield's bonus as normal.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and Aquan.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your walking speed is 25 feet.

entries.name: Home Is Where The Hearth Is
entries: You know the {@spell mold earth|XGE} cantrip and can cast it at will. In addition, you can spend an hour crafting a korpokkur home large enough for 10 medium creatures, provided the ground is earth. A creature you completes a long rest inside this home gains temporary hit points equal to half their level rounded down (minimum 1). You can spend another hour to unmake the home, leaving no trace of you having been there.

entries.name: Skilled Potter
entries: You have proficiency with {@item potter's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and {@language Kuma|KGtSeigai}.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: You have a walking and climbing speed of 25 feet.

entries.name: Animal Empathy
entries: Whenever you make a Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check related to primates or tamed animal species, you are considered proficient in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Forager
entries: You have advantage on rolls for foraging for food.

entries.name: Light-Footed and Light-Tailed
entries: You have advantage on {@skill Stealth} rolls when you're at a higher elevation than the person/people trying to detect you.

entries.name: Prehensile Tail
entries: Your tail is dexterous enough to use basic tools, pick up objects, and hold you hanging from something. Your tail cannot wield weapons or a shield.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic}, and you can speak {@language primate|KGtSeigai}. Primate does not have a written language.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your walking speed is 30 feet, and you have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Draconic Ancestry
entries: You have draconic ancestry. Choose one type of dragon from the Draconic Ancestry table. Your Godai Spirit Powers are determined by the dragon type, as shown in the table.

entries.name: Godai Spirit
entries: You can cast the cantrip associated with your draconic ancestry at well. When you reach 5th level, you can cast the Seijin Spell associated with your draconic ancestry once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. When you reach 11th level, you can cast the Teinen Spell associated with your draconic ancestry once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Size
entries: When in humanoid form, you are a Medium creature. When in anthropomorphic form, you are a Small creature.

entries.name: Speed
entries: When in humanoid or anthropomorphic form, your walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Bakemono
entries: You can use an action to shapeshift into your beast form, into a humanoid, or into an anthropomorphic (semi-humanoid) form halfway between the two. Your appearance in all three forms is hereditary just like any other race, and any equipment you wear in your human form adjusts to the size of your anthropomorphic form. When shifted into your beast form, the following rules apply:

items: Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the beast, but you retain your alignment, personality, hit points, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiences, in addition to gaining those of the beast. If the beast has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the beast's bonus instead of yours.

You can't cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn't break your concentration on a spell you've already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as {@spell call lightning|phb}, that you've already cast.

You retain the benefit of any features from your class or other sources and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as darkvision, unless your new form also has that sense.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature's shape and size. Your equipment doesn't change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can't wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak {@language Seigai Draconic|KGtSeigai|Draconic} and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Shapechanger
entries: In Seigai when a beast reaches a certain age, there is a chance they will grow into a bakemono, meaning "shapechanger." While this has been known to happen to many kinds of beasts, there are five that show a particular capability of making this ascent: cats, otters, foxes, badgers, and raccoon-dogs. Why this happens, no-one is particularly sure, although there are a number of theories (one even states it is directly related to the amount of lamp oil the creature has consumed in its life).

Shapechangers live mostly among their own tribes in the wild, however they have been known to make trips into urban centres, often out of mere curiosity. When interacting with folk from other races, a shapechanger will almost always adopt a humanoid or anthropomorphic form. Even in their humanoid forms, shapechangers have distinct characteristics that belie their true nature; it is often their tail that gives them away.

items.name: Bakeneko (Cat)
entries: Cats are often kept as house pets in Seigai, with the added benefit of keeping rodents and other pests out of the home. Seiganese people highly venerate domesticated cats, due to the chance that a cat will awaken as it reaches old age. Poorly treated cats who awaken into bakeneko often devote their time to tormenting their former owners. A well-kept bakeneko may live quite happily in society. Tribes of bakeneko are rare, and they are usually only seen in ones or twos.

items.name: Kawauso (Otter)
entries: Kawauso are river otters who have awakened as they have aged. They are famous for their dietary choices; for example, as their habitat often contains a lot of competition for food, the kawauso have learned how to break the defences of large crustaceans, prying open their chitinous armor. If they have one culinary vice, it is a love of sake. Give a kawauso a cup of your best sake and they will be your ally forever, it is said.

items.name: Kitsune (Fox)
entries: There is a special reverence for foxes among the people of Seigai. They are often thought of as the messengers of the {@i kami}, particularly {@deity Yōnō-sama|Seigai Pantheon|KGtSeigai}. However, the {@i kami} do not always bring good tidings. The Seigai people can be quite superstitious, and if a person appears too cunning, they may be accused of being a kitsune bringing a bad omen. Of all the shapechangers, kitsune are the most adept at hiding their true nature.

items.name: Mujina (Badger)
entries: I must confess I have never had the pleasure of meeting a mujina—at least to my knowledge. Mujina are the least likely to be seen among urban society, preferring to spend their time deep in the forests and away from the complications of bureaucracy. In fact, I have heard they are so introverted, that often they will learn how to adopt a frightening faceless form called {@i nopperabō} just to avoid a conversation.

items.name: Tanuki (Raccoon-Dog)
entries: While on my travels, I would occasionally encounter one of these portly furry creatures, mostly in rural areas. The tanuki bear some resemblance to raccoons and pandas, however I do believe they are unrelated. I have heard it said that the male tanuki have abnormally large scrota; while I have not seen this in person, I did notice many of them wearing baggy trousers.

feat.name: Sonon Mastery
entries: You have proven your ability to the gatekeepers of {@i sonon}. You have been entrusted with a secret {@i sonon} word that would destroy anyone not strong enough to utter it. Knowledge of this word has enhanced one of your skills. Increase the skill of your choice according to the table below by 1, to a maximum of 20, to represent this enhancement.

entries.name: Sonon Ability
entries: You gain one of the following abilities, corresponding to the {@i sonon} word you learned. The starting size of the Sonon die used by these abilities is a d6.

items.name: Rī Strike
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit with an attack roll, you can roll your Sonon die after you make the damage roll and add it to the total damage.

items.name: Shu Incantation
entries: Whenever you make a spellattack, you can roll your Sonon die and add the number rolled to the attack roll. You can choose to do so before or after rolling the d20, but before you know whether the attack hit.

items.name: Kan Technique
entries: Whenever you make a skill check for a skill you are proficient in, you can roll your Sonon die and add the number rolled to the check. You can choose to do so before or after rolling the d20, but before you know whether the check succeeded.

items.name: Ken Blessing
entries: Whenever you or an ally within 30 feet makes a saving throw, you can use your reaction to roll your Sonon die and add the number rolled to the saving throw. You can choose to do so before or after rolling the d20, but before you know whether the saving throw succeeded.

entries.name: Changing the Die's Size
entries: When you roll your Sonon die, it decreases by one die size after the roll. This represents you burning through your Sonon energy. For example, if the die is a d6, it becomes a d4. The minimum die size is a d4.

If you roll a 1 on your Sonon die, you are overwhelmed by the force of the Sonon flowing through you, and you take psychic damage equal to the maximum roll of the Sonon die. The die then shrinks to a d4.

Whenever you finish a long rest, your Sonon die resets to its starting size. When you reach certain levels, the starting size of your Sonon die increases: at 5th level (d8), 11th level (d10), and 17th level (d12). If you take the Sonon Mastery feat more than one time, you don't get more than one die.

entries.name: Sonon Replenishment
entries: As a bonus action, you can calm your mind for a moment and restore your Sonon die to its starting size. You then can't use Sonon Replenishment again until you finish a long rest

feat.name: Bayashi
entries: You have become an expert of mischievous illusion, continuing the ancestral line of legendary tanuki.

items: When you cast {@spell phantasmal force} with your Tanuki Magic racial ability, you can instead drum on your belly as the somatic component of the spell, to create an illusion known as bayashi. When casting {@spell phantasmal force} in this way, the illusion you create has no visual appearance; instead, you create the sound of ghostly drumming at a location of your choice within 60 feet. As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the locationg of the illusion up ot 20 feet..

feat.name: Nopperabō
entries: You have mastered shapechanging, to the point where you have some control over the form you assume.

items: You learn the {@spell disguise self} spell and can cast it a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, regaining any expended uses when you finish a long rest.

While in your humanoid form, you can use an action to temporarily take the appearance of a {@i nopperabō}, a humanoid with no facial features. Each creature of your choice within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier). A target automatically succeeds on the save if it can't see you. On a failed save, a target becomes {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute, or until you dispel your {@i nopperabō} appearance with a bonus action (whichever occurs first). If the frightened target takes any damage, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Once you have used this ability, you are unable to use it again until you have finished a short or long rest.

feat.name: Spirit Fox
entries: As kitsune age and garner experience, they can ascend up the ranks of the kitsune, becoming a spiritual being. You have lived many years and have been granted a rank on the first rung of the spiritual ladder, known as {@i kiko}.

items: You grow an additional tail, up ot a maximum of nine tails.

spell.name: Investiture of Aether
entries: The air around you stills as you command complete control of the aether. Until the spell ends, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are immune to thunder damage and have resistance to force damage.

You create an aura of silence centered on you with a radius of 20 feet. While inside the radius, all creatures other than yourself are unable to cast spells with a vibration component, and they are {@condition deafened} until they leave the aura.

You can use your action to unleash a wave of {@i sonon} energy. Each creature of your choice within your aura of silence must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 3d6} thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spell.name: Seijin of Aether
entries: The air around you stills as you command complete control of the aether. Until the spell ends, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are resistant to thunder damage.
Until the spell ends, any attack you make deals {@dice 2d6} extra thunder damage when you hit a creature within 10 feet of you

spell.name: Seijin of Flame
entries: Flames race across your body, shedding bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet for the spell's duration. The flames don't harm you. Until the spell ends, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are resistant to fire damage.
Until the spell ends, any attack you make deals {@dice 2d6} extra fire damage when you hit a creature within 10 feet of you

spell.name: Seijin of Ice
entries: Until the spell ends, ice rimes your body, and you gain the following benefits:

items: You are resistant to cold damage.
Until the spell ends, any attack you make deals {@dice 2d6} extra cold damage when you hit a creature within 10 feet of you

spell.name: Seijin of Stone
entries: Until the spell ends, bits of rock spread across your body, and you gain the following benefits:

items: You can use your action to create a small earthquake on the ground in a 5-foot radius centered on you. Other creatures on that ground must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.
Until the spell ends, any attack you make deals {@dice 2d6} extra bludgeoning damage when you hit a creature within 10 feet of you

spell.name: Seijin of Wind
entries: Until the spell ends, wind whirls around you, and you gain the following benefits:

items: Ranged weapon attacks made against you have disadvantage on the attack roll.
Until the spell ends, any attack you make deals {@dice 2d6} extra slashing damage when you hit a creature within 10 feet of you

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the filthlicker has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). If this attack is a critical hit, the target also can't breathe or speak until the grapple ends.

A filthlicker ({@i akaname} in Draconic) may appear like a child at first sight. They are typically unkempt with long hair and tattered garb. Their defining characteristic is their long tongue which can extend the length of their entire body. They use this tongue to feed off putrid muck.
A filthlicker will often ignore you unless you begin to start cleaning, at which point they will turn violent.

monster.name: Lion-Dog
languages: understands Seigai Draconic and Kami but can't speak them

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The lion-dog is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The lion-dog's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Living Statue
entries: The lion-dog does not need to eat, drink, breathe, or sleep, and does not age. While motionless, the lion-dog is indistinguishable from a statue.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lion-dog's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). It can cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lion-dog makes two attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

In significant sacred spaces, you will often find a pair of lion-dogs at the entrance. Their appearance will be that of stone; the one on the left bares their teeth and represents the {@i a} (the beginning), while the one on the right keeps their lips closed representing the {@i un} (the end).
When the sacred space is threatened, the lion-dogs will awake from their petrified slumber and fiercely defend the holy place and its inhabitants

trait.name: Swimming Leap
entries: With a 10-foot swimming start, the dragon can long jump out of or across the water, up to 25 feet.

action.name: Bite

trait.name: Telepathic Bond
entries: The Amanojaku ignores the range restriction on its telepathy when communicating with a creature it has {@condition charmed}. The two don't even need to be on the same plane of existence.

trait.name: Moral Compass
entries: Whenever a creature the Amanojaku can see voluntarily moves across an imaginary line that extends South-West from the Amanojaku, they must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed} for 1 day. While {@condition charmed}, the Amanojaku has access to all the most selfish and evil desires of the target's heart. The {@condition charmed} target obeys any of the Amanojaku's verbal or telepathic commands to act on their selfish instinct. If the target suffers any harm or receives a command to harm itself, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success. If the target successfully saves against the effect, or if the effect on it ends, the target is immune to this Amanojaku's Charm for the next 24 hours.
The Amanojaku can have only one target {@condition charmed} at a time. If it charms another, the effect on the previous target ends.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Amanojaku makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Oni makes two kanabō attacks.

action.name: Kanabō
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Demon Gate
entries: Whenever a creature the Oni can see voluntarily moves across an imaginary line that extends South-West from the Oni, the Oni can use its reaction to move up to 10 feet towards the creature and make an attack against the creature.

trait.name: Feathered Fool
entries: Kotengu are overconfident creatures and easily tricked. The Kotengu has disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks.

trait.name: Winged Arms
entries: While flying, the Kotengu is unable to make ranged weapon attacks unless directly above the target. The Kotengu can still grasp items with its feet and make melee weapon attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage in melee, or 3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage at range, or 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage if used with both hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Tantrum
entries: When the Kotengu has its hit points reduced below maximum, it enters a tantrum, and uses it reaction to move up to 30 feet in the direction of the attacker and make an attack with its spear.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The Daitengu adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the Daitengu must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

reaction.name: Counter-Flank
entries: When the Daitengu is hit by an attack that has advantage due to flanking, they can make one attack against the attacker with their naginata.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The fox has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Claws

entries.name: Ō-Ryū
entries: All {@i ō-ryū} dragons start out life in a larval form. These are the carp dragons. A famous folk story states that carp dragons ascend to adulthood once they can leap over the Heavenly Falls on the River Zaikara. (The truth is disappointingly more mundane; adulthood more of a gradual transformation. However, carp dragons are well aware of the tale. If you spot a carp dragon jumping up a waterfall, they are laughing at you behind your back.)

Once matured, the {@i ō-ryū} will have developed into one of five categories of {@i ō-ryū} each having an affinity to and origin born of the five elements: {@i chiryū} (Earth), {@i suiryū} (Water), {@i karyū} (Fire), {@i fūryū} (Air), and {@i kūryū} (Void). Each family of dragons has an elder dragon {@i kami} from whom they all descend; for instance, Chinushi-sama is the dragon {@i kami} for the {@i chiryū} family (Earth dragons), and the Emperor Suinushi-sama is the dragon {@i kami} for the {@i suiryū} family (Water dragons).

Unlike the chromatic and metallic dragons who inhabit other lands, the adult {@i ō-ryū} are nebulous creatures with no clear consistent morality: at one moment the wisest creatures one could ever meet; the next, incomparably cruel and vindictive. However, they are often quite reclusive. Most Seiganese people will never meet a dragon.

items.name: Earth Dragons
entries: The Earth dragons, known as {@i chiryū}, are the weakest of all the {@i ō-ryū}—and yet, they hold all the political power in Seigai. Their progenitor is Chinushi-sama, the eight-forked serpent of Koshi, and this affords them special status due to their shared lineage with the {@i chinushi-zu daimyō}.
To identify an Earth dragon, look for its sandy scales and algae-green hair. You will know an Earth dragon has been in town recently if the streets need repaving.

items.name: Water Dragons
entries: While Earth dragons may hold the most political power of the {@i ō-ryū}, they are not the most numerous. That title is held by the Water dragons, who inhabit the many lakes and wide open seas of Seigai.

The Emperor Suinushi-sama is the highest of all the {@i suiryū}, as they are known. While he held office for many centuries, no Water dragon is ever truly at home on dry land; reports say he is much happier in his exile in Ryūgū-jō.

Water dragons have scales of teal-green to aquamarine. Their form is more streamlined and their feet are webbed to aid in propulsion through the depths. Their diet usually consists of large sharks and squid.

items.name: Fire Dragons
entries: The first Fire dragon was born of the {@i kami} Shōjō-sama, who did not survive the labor. The newborn was given the name Kanushi-sama, meaning the "Lord of Fire", and later slain in retribution.

Kanushi-sama's offspring are rarely seen, other than around volcanic eruptions, such as the centennial eruption of Mount Yamabi. When they do appear, {@i karyū} are often mistaken for the {@i ho-o} at a distance, so they are often treated interchangeably in folk tales.

items.name: Air Dragons
entries: While all {@i ō-ryū} can fly, none take to the sky quite as elegantly as the {@i fūryū}—the Air dragons. I once saw a young {@i fūryū} over the mountains near Shikashi; the creature twirled through the sky like a ribbon. From a distance I could still observe the white-lilac scales and flowing silver hair, and I was moved to tears.
Not long after, I was standing out in the cold rain, soaked to the skin. Air dragons are often found riding the winds of a storm front.

The ancestor of the Air dragons, Fūnushi-sama, was emerged from the blood of Kanushi-sama as it pooled in Shōdan-sama's clenched sword-hand. They are known as the "Lord of Rain and Snow", and is especially called upon by the Seiganese people during seasons of drought.

items.name: Void Dragons
entries: Of all the {@i ō-ryū}, the least is understood about the Void dragons, or {@i kūryū} in Seiganese. They are native to the land of the {@i kami}, rarely interacting with our world. Their presence seems to disrupt the weave, causing {@i sonon} to dissipate into silence.

Kūnushi-sama is one of the four celestial guardians of Seigai, visible in the night sky to the East. When the moon is in Kūnushi-sama's Heart Mansion, the Seiganese people hold a festival called Kūmatsuri in honor of their silent protector.

entries.name: Oni
entries: The {@i oni} are the most feared of all the {@i yōkai}, and tales of their deeds make up the majority of the Seiganese ghost stories known as {@i kaidan}.

An {@i oni} is formed when an individual has wandered so far down the path of evil that all hope of redemption is lost. Their skin will begin to change color; horns will sprout from their head; they will grow supernaturally strong; and their obsession: causing others to suffer.

Never allow an {@i oni} to station itself North-East of you. This is the {@i kimon}, or "demon gate", where the {@i oni's} powers are strongest. However, regardless of where, an {@i oni} encounter will usually spell your doom.

entries.name: Tengu
entries: Two varieties of tengu exist, and while they are often in league, they are certainly quite unlike each other.

The kotengu is perhaps similar to a bird who stands erect like a human. Their arms are covered in greasy feathers allowing them to fly, although devoid of a swallow's grace, as they must flap their arms vigorously to stay aloft. Their garb usually consists of clothes stolen from the bodies of their ambush victims, and they frighten passersby with their loud chattering squawks. They are, put simply, a violent nuisance, and responsible for the majority of missing travelers on Shōdanshima's roads.

Meanwhile, daitengu are everything in countenance that a kotengu is not. The daitengu resembles a tall human with a long phallic nose and red skin. They too are capable of short flight, using the marbled wings that sprout from their backs. Daitengu are capable {@i sonon} users and skilled with the blade, which is expertise they may share—if you can prove yourself worthy. To find a daitengu, look to the mountains, so it is said.

baseitem.name: Mino
entries: A cape made of straw, useful in a pinch.

entries.name: Special
entries: Destroyed when wearer takes fire damage.

baseitem.name: Manchira
entries: A mail shirt, worn under clothes.

baseitem.name: Kusari
entries: Light mail armor.

baseitem.name: Hayokpe
entries: A leather laminar armor with ankle-length skirts, worn by the hunters of Rep-un-Mosir.

baseitem.name: Kikko
entries: Folding armor consisting of hexagonal plates linked by kusari mail.

baseitem.name: Karuta
entries: Folding armor consisting of hexagonal plates linked by kusari mail.

baseitem.name: Kozane dō
entries: Lamellar cuirass made of scales.

baseitem.name: Tosei dō
entries: Iron-plate cuirass designed to protect against gunfire.

baseitem.name: Dō-maru
entries: Riveted suit of whole-body lamellar armor.

baseitem.name: Ō-yoroi
entries: Ornate riveted suit of whole-body lamellar armor, boxy in shape and designed for horseback combat.

baseitem.name: Tosei-gusoku
entries: Iron-plate whole-body armor designed to protect against gunfire.

baseitem.name: Tosei-gusoku with auxiliaries
entries: Iron-plate whole-body armor designed to protect against gunfire, plus auxiliary pieces for further defence.

baseitem.name: Tedate
entries: Rectangular wooden or iron-plate shield.

baseitem.name: Ararebō
entries: A short mace, held in one hand.

baseitem.name: Aribo
entries: A small club.

baseitem.name: Bō
entries: A quarterstaff.

baseitem.name: Hanbō
entries: A short quarterstaff.

baseitem.name: Kabutowari
entries: A dagger designed for piercing helmets.

baseitem.name: Kama
entries: A sickle.

baseitem.name: Kanamuchi
entries: A long thin metal club.

baseitem.name: Nage-yari
entries: A short spear or javelin.

baseitem.name: Ono
entries: A handaxe.

baseitem.name: Yari
entries: A straight-headed spear.

baseitem.name: Yoroi-dōshi
entries: A small dagger.

baseitem.name: Hankyū
entries: A shortbow.

baseitem.name: Shudo
entries: A light crossbow.

baseitem.name: Shuriken
entries: A small bladed throwing weapon with rotational symmetry.

baseitem.name: Chigiriki
entries: A flail.

baseitem.name: Fuetsu
entries: A battleaxe.

baseitem.name: Jitte
entries: A thin steel baton with a hook at the hilt used for disarming

entries.name: Special
entries: When you attack with this weapon, you can choose whether the damage is piercing or bludgeoning. Then, you can use a bonus action to {@action disarm|dmg} a target.

baseitem.name: Jūmonji-yari
entries: A three-pronged yari spear.

baseitem.name: Kama-yari
entries: A yari spear with an additional blade at a right-angle to the thrusting blade.

baseitem.name: Kanabō
entries: A heavy, two-handed maul, also known as a testubō.

baseitem.name: Katana
entries: A longsword with a curved blade, carried by {@i samurai} and some {@i rōnin}.

baseitem.name: Kusari-fundo
entries: A bludgeoning flail.

baseitem.name: Kusarigama
entries: A flail with a kama sickle on the end.

baseitem.name: Masakari
entries: A greataxe.

baseitem.name: Muchi
entries: A whip.

baseitem.name: Nagamaki
entries: A longsword similar to a katana, notable for its long handle.

baseitem.name: Naginata
entries: A spear-like weapon with a slicing blade attached to the end.

baseitem.name: Ninjatō
entries: A shortsword used by {@i shinobi} warriors.

baseitem.name: Nunchaku
entries: A weapon made from two wooden sticks attached by a chain.

baseitem.name: Ōdachi
entries: A large longsword, longer than a katana.

baseitem.name: Ōtsuchi
entries: A warhammer, particularly used as a siege weapon.

baseitem.name: Sai
entries: A short piercing weapon with two curved prongs at the hilt used for disarming.

entries.name: Special
entries: When you attack with this weapon, you can choose whether the damage is piercing or bludgeoning. Then, you can use a bonus action to {@action disarm|dmg} a target.

baseitem.name: Tessen
entries: A war fan, used for striking and deflecting attacks

entries.name: Special
entries: If you are proficient with martial weapons, you may increase your Armor Class by 1 while wielding a tessen. If you attack with the tessen, you lose this bonus and regain it at the start of your next turn. You can benefit from only one tessen at a time.

baseitem.name: Tsurugi
entries: A greatsword. Used widely in the Setsuritsu period, but fallen out of favor.

baseitem.name: Tsuruhashi
entries: A war pick.

baseitem.name: Uchigatana
entries: A type of sword similar to a katana, but mass produced and of inferior construction.

baseitem.name: Wakizashi
entries: A shortsword, usually carried with a katana.

baseitem.name: Daikyū
entries: A longbow.

baseitem.name: Fukiya
entries: A blowgun.

baseitem.name: Bo-hiya
entries: A mortar that uses matchlock technology. Fires a large iron arrow set aflame.

entries.name: Special
entries: Upon a hit, everything within 5 ft of the target must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Dexterity modifier) or suffer {@damage 1d8} fire damage. If the weapon misses, the ammunition bounces away harmlessly. Once used, the bo-hiya cannot be fired again until an action has been used to reload the weapon.

baseitem.name: Tanegashima
entries: The matchlock rifles used by Chinushi Nobunaga's forces that allowed him to gain military superiority over the other {@i daimyō}.

table.name: Table of Prominent Kami
rows: The Female-Who-Invites. Among the first deities. With her husband Shōdan-sama, created the land of Seigai, and birthed the rest of the {@i kami}.
The Male-Who-Invites. Among the first deities. With his wife Shōjō-sama, created the land of Seigai, and sired the rest of the {@i kami}.
The Heaven-Shining-Great-August-Deity. The great goddess of the Sun, supreme among the deities. Tenshō-sama ordained Suinushi-sama as Emperor.
His Augustness, Moon-Night Possessor. A brother of Tenshō-sama, and governs the light of the moon. He and Tenshō-sama have an ancient quarrel, hence they are in different parts of the sky.
His-Swift-Impetuous-Male-Augustness. Another brother of Tenshō-sama, and also in conflict with her. Through his cunning, Ran-sama slew Chinushi-sama, giving rise to the {@i chinushi-zu}.

Her Augustness, Heavenly-Alarming-Female. The goddess of the dawn and revelry. When Tenshō-sama once went into hiding, Inga-sama made the other {@i kami} laugh so much that Tenshō-sama came out of hiding to see what the commotion was about.
The Prince-of-Long-Wind. The god of the wind, and often paired with Kaminari-sama in holy places. Kaze-sama has a terrifying green-skinned appearance and carries a bag of wind around his shoulders.
The Eight Thunder-Deities. The god of storms, and often paired with Kaze-sama in holy places. Kaminari-sama has a similarly terrifying appearance, and carries with him the taiko drums of thunder.
The goddess of fertility and agriculture. Yōnō-sama has a close relationship with the kitsune, and is often depicted with a fox-like appearance. She is the most widely venerated {@i kami} in Seigai.
The Eight-Banners-Deity. The divine protector of Seigai and the god of warriors. The Azure invoke Bushi-sama before going into battle.
The Shining-Elder. The {@i kami} of fire. The trauma of giving birth to Kanushi-sama killed Shōjō-sama, which sent her to the underworld.
The Many-Minds'-Thought-Combining Deity. Sōbai-sama is the great mediator, the most wise of the {@i kami}.
The guardian of pools, lakes, seas, and the ocean, and all who reside in them. Also the goddess of the sewers.
